title: mum-says-i-literally-begging-people-save-life
story: Trudie Murphy is hoping to fly out to the USA for treatment which could see the tumour removed.She was given the horrible news last week that specialists in Scotland would be unable to remove the cancerous tumour, while chemotherapy was also not an option.Doctors have said that she could receive radiotherapy but it would be as a last resort to extend her le.Now, a close friend, Colin Rillie-Caldwell, has launched an online appeal looking to raise more than pound,, which would be used to cover the cost of treatment.Trudie, who works part-time in Tranentrsquos Asda store, admitted to the Courier she was ldquopessimistic but would love the money to be raised to give her extra time with her children.She said: ldquoI would love to see it happen, to be able to be around for my kids ndash that is my sole driving force.ldquoThis GoFundMe page, I feel embarrassed because I feel like it is begging but I thought: lsquoI am literally begging for people to save my le so that I am here for my kids.rsquoldquoRight now, I just feel like somebody has put a plastic bag over my head and is slowly tightening it and I cannot breathe.ldquoIt is the last thing you think about at night and the first thing you think about in the morning.ldquoYou automatically think you would have it removed and have chemotherapy but to be told that you cannot, that they will not go in and do anythinghellipThe Tranent mum had been referred to hospital for brain and spinal MRIs after it was thought she had MS .However, the scans showed it was worse than first thought, with Trudie, who is mum to Joshand Naomi , who attend Ross High School, Zak , who will be starting at Knox Academy Meadowpark, and eight-year-old Archie, who attends Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, in Tranent, saying she ldquofelt numb after being told she had an inoperable brain tumour.A biopsy and chemotherapy have both been ruled out by experts due to the location of the tumour.She said: ldquoThey donrsquot know how aggressive it is because they cannot do the biopsy.ldquoThey were throwing everything at me ndash there are  types of brain cancer. They donrsquot know how quick it is going to grow.ldquoIrsquove been told I will start to have epileptic fits, I will lose my mobility and even simple things like swallowing I will be unable to do.With options on the NHS limited, Trudie and her husband Dave, who tied the knot  months ago, are looking at the possibility of travelling to America or other countries for treatment.Trudie, who has lived in Tranent for about eight years after previously living in Musselburgh, where she attended the townrsquos secondary school, said a hospital in America could use a needle ldquoas thin as a hair to take a biopsy, while the possibility of operating on the tumour had not been ruled out.Unfortunately, that would mean raising thousands of pounds to cover expensive medical bills.Friends and family rallied round for the online appeal, with more than pound, already raised.Trudie, , encouraged people to get in touch with raffle prizes for a future fundraiser and said: ldquoPeople can surprise you.ldquoIt is not always the people you are closest to that reach out but people I have not spoken to for a while that reach out to you."There are strangers I have never met that are donating money to somebody that they donrsquot know, especially just now because of lockdown.ldquoEverybody has been affected by this financially one way or another and I certainly did not expect to get over pound,.Dave, who works as a residential childcare worker in Ormiston, described the news as ldquodevastating.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to put it into words."She is so young, has so much to give and has so much to look forward to for this to potentially take her away, knowing potentially that something can be done ndash there are no words.To support Trudie, go to gofundme f treatment-for-trudie

title: plans-car-park-elcho-green-shelved
story: Councillors and council officials have this week been inundated with angry comments from disbelieving residents, protesting against cherished recreational area Elcho Green, at North Berwickrsquos West Bay, being utilised for an -space long-stay car park.The local authority said in a statement last Tuesday that, as part of ious measures inNorth Berwick to provide extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-, including widening pavements at the east end of High Street, it would be ldquoconverting part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.It stated that ldquofollowing a meeting with local traders, North Berwick CommunityCouncil and North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, agreement has been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town ndash but both the community council and area partnership told the Courier they had not given backing to the Elcho Green changes.The councilrsquos own timetable had Elcho Green car park opening last Friday .An online petition, West Bay not Parking Bay, to ldquoprotect stunning and iconic West Bay in North Berwick, was launched by resident Sarah Russell and had attracted more than , signatures in less than a week.It said: ldquoEast Lothian Council have announced plans to turn Elcho Green into a longstay car park.ldquoWhilst the council state that this is a temporary measure to comply with their Covid Spaces for People initiative, it is greatly feared that this will, in fact, lead to a permanent car park in the most iconic seafront location in East Lothian."North Berwick residents and visitors alike will be robbed of the very essence of this beautul recreational space that personies this famous conservation area seafront.ldquoTemporary or otherwise, Elcho Green is not the correct location for any car parking and we would urge you to help us stop this environmental catastrophe.Among those supporting the campaign was world-famous golfer and North Berwick resident Catriona Matthew, captain of Europersquos winning Solheim Cup team.The Courier has been swamped with letters and emails against the plans .The scheme was described as ldquoindefensible and ldquoundemocratic vandalism by some residents, while many asked why there had not been specic consultation on the plan and highlighted that the land had been gted to the town by the late Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple for recreational use in .On Monday, East Lothian Council released a statement that it was placing the ldquoElcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult.It is the second time in a month that the councilrsquos plans to transform town centres have hit the buffers.Earlier in July, proposals to suspend parking in town centres were put ldquoon hold after traders and residents in Haddington reacted with anger as cones and parking suspension signs were put up overnight, sparking widespread concern.In Mondayrsquos statement, Councillor Norman Hampshire , environment spokesperson, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has successfully implemented a number of physical distancing measures on North Berwick High Street to support the need for safe access to the town centre and economic recovery.ldquoA further support for Spaces for People was a proposal to utilise a small part of Elcho Green in North Berwick as a temporary car park.ldquoThe benefit of this would have been a reduction in the number of vehicles circling and queuing for parking spaces, enhanced safety for pedestrians and cyclists within the town centre, and improved air quality.ldquoEast Lothian Council is a listening authority and we are aware of the ious perspectives being raised within the North Berwick community.ldquoAs such, we intend to place the Elcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult."This delay will also enable us to monitor the impact of increased traffic as a result of visitors and to assess the effectiveness of measures introduced.Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, said that recent u-turns were down to a ldquolack of political leadership within the Labour administration.He said he received more than  emails objecting to the Elcho Green plans.He called for a report on the Spaces for People plans, and in particular parking proposals in North Berwick, to be put before a meeting of elected council group leaders in two weeksrsquo time for approval.Under emergency Covid- procedures, normal council business is currently suspended and decisions are taken at monthly meetings of the group leaders and council chief executive.He said: ldquoThe decision must be approved by councillors at the leadersrsquo group meeting and it should be open and transparent and open to the press.Mr Hampshire accused Mr Currie of ldquoplaying politics in ldquoan emergency situation.ldquoWe have allowed him to take part in the meetings with officers at every point during the discussions, said Mr Hampshire.ldquoI have got to say the Conservative Group have been fully behind what we are doing."For the SNP to try to play politics in a situation where their own Government is instructing local authorities to create spaces in town centres is unbelievable.Conservative councillor Craig Hoy called on the administration to ldquotake notice of the recent problems caused by parking proposals.He said the Scottish Government had failed to give councils enough time to push through emergency Covid measures in town centres.Councillor Hoy said: "Scottish Councils are operating under huge pressure with limited resources, but that does not remove the need for them to consult fully and communicate clearly on big issues which impact our communities."I hope East Lothian Council and the Labour administration will take notice of the recent problems in North Berwick and fully engage with stakeholders."Hilary Smith, chair of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, stressed that the area partnership had not attended any meeting regarding Covid- plans for the town or given its approval to the plans.North Berwick Community Council said it had not discussed Elcho Green prior to its meeting on Tuesday.East Lothian Council received pound.million from Scottish Government funding for Spaces for People projects to make social distancing easier in town centres and encourage people toto them safely.The council launched a consultation in May, asking people for their county-wide views.It attracted , contributions and more than  comments, including more than  from the North Berwick area.But North Berwick residents have not been asked their specic views on Elcho Green car parking.The council said it had given consideration to parking availability at a number of sites in North Berwick.In response to questions from the Courier, the council said: ldquoThe high school and sports centre are both due to re-open in coming weeks so were unsuitable to use.ldquoAn area of Elcho Green is considered suitable to take traffic arriving from the west to park for people visiting the town to intercept the flow of traffic and stop vehicles circulating through the town unnecessarily searching for parking spaces and generating additional traffic pollution.ldquoIt also seemed reasonable considering the area of land is used annually for Fringe by the Sea events."A maximum of  places had been identied for use as a potential temporary car park which is not part of the Spaces for People grant but provided as part of the programme.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-reopens-doors-today
story: The coronavirus pandemic forced the venue to close in mid-March but now preparations have been made and put in place for its reopening.The Seabird Centre, which is an independent charity, will open Thursday-Sunday, am-pm, in what it describes as a ldquohugely positive step.It will then close Monday-Wednesday to allow staff to review the visitor experience over the temporary opening time and make improvements where needed.Staff at the centre are ldquoreally excited to welcome people back and hope to be back to a daily am-pm opening from next Thursday .Several new processes are in place to help manage numbers and ensure everyone can visit safely, including a new booking system.The number of people allowed in at any one time will be signicantly reduced to about  per cent of normal capacity to allow for physical distancing.Because of this reduction, the Seabird Centre will only be able to earn a fraction of its usual income, meaning its future in the months ahead ldquoremains challenging.Having to suddenly close its doors in March due to Covid- had a ldquodevastating effect on the Seabird Centrersquos finances as it was forced to close at the beginning of the summer tourism season, something it relies on.In May it launched its first-ever urgent public appeal, which saw it aim to raise pound, and save it from permanent closure. story: Scottish Government-imposed restrictions to help fight the coronavirus pandemic were relaxed last week, with customers allowed back inside pubs, provided they followed social distancing.Businesses throughout the county were pleased to welcome back thirsty punters, with each reporting a busy weekend.Laura McSweeney, from The Green in Haddington, was pleased with how the weekend had gone.She said people had been ldquorespectful of the restrictions in place and the beer garden was proving popular, with the exception of during poor weather.She added: ldquoIt has been a bit of a mixture to be honest. allowed to bring their empty glasses back to the bar.Similar to The Green, there is also a rigorous cleaning regime in place as well.William Gordon, manager at The Brig Inn in Tranent, said the beer garden had been full and there had been a good number of visitors.He added that ious restrictions had also been put in place but people seemed to be enjoying themselves.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell, local area commander, had attended Haddingtonrsquos community council, which was held online, last week.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the group, asked what measures police were putting in place ahead of the first weekend of people drinking inside pubs.The senior officer said that licensing officers had liaised with each of the licensed premises across East Lothian ahead of them reopening.He noted that many were simply too small to have a great number of visitors when social distancing was taken into account and officers would be out over the weekend.He said: ldquoRight through the whole of East Lothian, [licensed premises] are really keen to make sure they provide a safe environment for customers.ldquoIf they do that, there will be far less people within their premises.ldquoWe will deal with any complaints in the normal manner.Writing in his Courier column this week, Ch Insp Mitchell was pleased to say that the weekend had gone smoothly.He wrote: ldquoOur licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.

title: pictures-prestonpans-lockdown-gala-day
story: Like many events in the county, the annual Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala was impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The galarsquos organising committee had several discussions and, following advice from both East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government, it first postponed and then cancelled the gala day, which had been due to be held on June .However, the committee still wanted to recognise and mark the day.One suggestion was to give all of those in the royal court a goodie bag and rename the event, so instead it held what it called lsquoLockdown Gala Dayrsquo.Graeme Hutchison, gala convenor, told the Courier: ldquoThis was to encourage the kids and remind them that we hadnrsquot forgotten that this should have been their special day.ldquoThis idea kind of grew thanks to our chairperson Vikki Burns suggesting we could have an alternative gala day parade.The parade consisted of the gala committee members decorating their cars with balloons and bows in gala colours.They then travelled around Prestonpans, stopping at the houses of each member of the royal court to deliver them their goodie bag, honking their horns as they passed.Graeme said: ldquoIn the lead-up to gala day there was still a buzz about the town people were still showing their support by putting up their bunting and the parents of the royal court were being made aware we would be visiting. Nobody knew what to expect.ldquoGala day itself was amazing, from the glorious weather to the great response we got from the locals as we travelled around in convoy tooting and waving, visiting many streets of the town which the normal gala parade doesnrsquot visit. The people of Prestonpans certainly came out to show their support and for that we are truly grateful.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank the future Queen Lily [Bennion] and her royal court, as well as their families for their patience and understanding. Thanks to Connor from Sneddon Media for travelling with us and capturing the fantastic photos, which are on our Facebook page lsquoPrestonpans Gala Dayrsquo.ldquoFinally, thanks to the dedicated committee members who once again gave up their time to make the event possible.ldquoWe hope to be back doing some fundraisers in the not too distant future to help us fund and prepare as we look forward to Gala Day  on Saturday, June .After Lockdown Gala Day, Graeme took to social media to share his thoughts on the event.He said: ldquoPrestonpans, you didnrsquot disappoint us.ldquoThe fantastic efforts made from everyone to put up your bunting and decorate your streets, please repeat this next year. It was great to see so many of you as we travelled around as many streets as we could while visiting the members of the royal court.ldquoTo the royal court children, we didnrsquot want to forget that it would have been your day, we can still have your special day next year.ldquoTo Queen Lily, you were absolutely stunning, even reducing some of the committee to tears your mum and dad will be proud of you, the way you conducted yourself on what should have been your special day. To you, the community of Prestonpans for coming out and showing your appreciation as we passed by quietlyin our cars, doing the alternative gala parade. Hopefully you enjoyed it.He also thanked his fellow gala committee members for giving up their time and ensuring gala day traditions continued.

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: cork-people-proud-show
story: "I feel I can do anything in front of the crew, which we have - theres not much of me that the crew hasnt seen!" quips the Cork-born star, .In the BBC comedy, Murphy plays Conor MacSweeney, whos best friends with Jock OKeeffe, played by fellow Corkonian, Chris Walley, .Over the past two series - spin-offs from the  film of the same name - we have followed the two loveable rogues as they get themselves into all sorts of sticky situations.Particularly memorable storylines include the teenagers attempt to steal a giant tuna fish from the market in series one, and when they got expelled after stripping off in the classroom and peeing on Principal Walshs leg in series two.Now were getting a series three, in which we see the lads trying to make their way as young adults, with yet more questionable methods of making some money, all while Jock navigates being a new dad.One things for sure things wont go smoothly.Here, we chat to Walley and Murphy, plus Hilary Rose - who plays Conors stressed-out but loving mum, Mairead - to find out more.NEW CHAPTERIts an unconventional family set-up in The Young Offenders, which is set and filmed in Cork.A heart-warming episode in series one saw widower Maireadbecome a foster mum to Jock - whose mum is also dead - after he escapes his abusive, alcoholic dad.At the end of series two, Jocks girlfriend Siobhan - whose dad happens to be Principal Walsh, who is far from the biggest fan of Jock and Conor - gave birth to baby Star .The new addition to the family means Principal Walsh and his we Orla - whose other daughter Linda is going out with Conor - now have to engage more with Mairead, which hasnt always gone well in the past."Season three was interesting from a character point of view because Mairead really cuts loose and, at some stages, the lads are telling her to calm down!" follows Rose, whos also from Cork, and married Peter Foott - who created The Young Offenders - since .As for the love story between her and Sergeant Healy, she teases "season three kinda continues that on-again, off-again, will they, wont they vibe".The main storyline for series two is how Jock is adjusting to everyday le with baby Star."Conor and Jock are still getting into their sticky situations but now theres just a baby there as well," reveals Walley."I think its just a major sht in their lives and theyre just trying to figure it out all together."PARENTING LESSONSTwins Nola and Penny Richardson shared the role of Star, and Walley says the babies were "incredible"."I want one!" exclaims Murphy, before quickly adding "not right now".Rose chimes in at this point, saying she has told the boys they are always welcome to babysit her kids ."Theyre both amazing babysitters, but there was a time when Jake was very young where they bought him a nerf gun," she recalls, which sets them all off laughing, with her on-screen sons looking a little sheepish."I dunno, we were buying toys and we were like, This is what kids that age like!" reasons Walley."There was some force off ityou shot it," he concedes. "Theyre heavy-duty.""That was a real Conor and Jock moment for the two of us," admits Murphy.Having Penny and Nola on set this series was definitely a learning curve for the young actors."I was terried of holding babies for fear I dropped them," confides Walley. "By the end of the shoot, I just was inseparable."MEMORABLE MOMENTSAccording to Murphy, "theres not a street in Cork city that we havent filmed on"."The Cork people are so proud of the show."Having crowds watching them film was something they "had to get used to pretty quick.""There was a great photo in the paper a few years ago, of us making the film there are about  people in the crew, no-ones watching us filming," notes Murphy."And then there was a photo of us making season , and there were just crowds of people watching."It was good, it was like doing a play every day, whenever we were filming outside in the city."One of the new episodes sees Jock, Conor and Mairead take a trip to Dublin.Whilst filming on a road in the Irish capital city, they reveal they were pulled over by Leo Varadkars entourage as he was driving past them in an unmarked executive car.The Irish politician was taoiseach at the time ."There was a camera in the back seat, and we were mid-scene and we were like, What does this guy want  Were filming!" says Rose."And eventually Alex put down the passenger window and was like Hey!, and next thing Leo Varadkar leaned forward!""His driver was like, Great show!" recalls Murphy. "We were like, Do you like it [to Varadkar] And he went, I havent seen it!""But he did say, Ive heard its great", adds Rose.CHARACTER DEVELOPMENTThe biggest thing Rose has taken away from making The Young Offenders is the amazing relationships theyve formed with cast and crew ."Its about getting the job done and doing the best that you can, but you have to remember as well, for actors, were really vulnerable in front of all the crew, so you kinda put your trust in them," she elaborates."If were doing emotional scenes, theyre witnessing it, theyre trying to support you."As for future series, Murphy points out the only issue could be that he and Walley dont exactly look  anymore."At some points in the script, Jock will go, We cant do that, were only , and we were like, Can we just not mention our age " he continues, chuckling."As long as we look young, I guess well see what happens. CGI is working pretty good these days..."The Young Offenders is available on BBC iPlayer and on BBC One from Friday.

title: gardening-tvs-carol-klein-shares-top-picks-longer-lasting-summer-plants
story: Did you buy summer bedding plants months ago, when they first went on sale and panic-buying was all around If so, you might have noticed they look a little tired by now, after the baking sun we had in May followed by endless rain.But, how can you plug the gaps to bring colour into your garden thatll last until the autumn TVs Carol Klein will be offering late summer gardening inspiration to visitors of the virtual RHS Flower Show Tatton Park at Home on July , hosted on the RHS website."You should go for perennials, because not only will they look good right through the summer and into the autumn, but they will keep coming back every year. They are much more worth the investment. Its not worth planting bedding plants at this time of year," says the BBC Gardeners World regular.You can enjoy a riot of colour with late-summer flowering perennials in shades ranging from zingy yellows to scorching reds and burnt oranges, which will last into October."Theres a huge group of plants which are all from the States, but which we think of as common English cottage garden plants, flowering from mid-summer onwards," adds Klein.Here are some of her recommendations...ASTERS"Michaelmas daisies start flowering as we go into August but then they will go right the way through," she says. "Aster novi-belgii is a tough aster which never seems to get disease and is ideal."They can be planted in summer, where you have gaps left by early-flowering plants, and grow to around cm. They prefer sun or light shade and should be kept well watered in dry soils. They make good companions with other autumn-flowering plants, including Japanese anemones.HELENIUMS"These plants, which are vaguely from the daisy family, are superb. If you keep on deadheading, they will flower right up to the end of September," says Klein. "They are just starting to flower. My favourite is Helenium El Dorado, which produces great big golden flowers, and Sahins Early Flowerer. There are lots of traditional ones, including Moerheim Beauty with its dark, copper-red daisy-like flowers, which are also popular."When you deadhead, cut down to the next bud on the stem, which will then flower and you can get a show through to autumn. Lt and ide heleniums every few years, which will increase your stock, Klein adds."If you split them in the spring, they almost fall apart for you. We do that with ours, planting three little pieces at a time."RUDBECKIASRudbeckias, also known as coneflowers because their bright yellow petals hang down, emphasising the prominent dark central cone, are from the same group of North American daisies. "Rudbeckia fulgida deemii or Goldsturm are both beautul," Klein enthuses.Goldsturm has such an abundance of flowers that it has an almost solid effect in the late summer border. Use the smaller ieties with fiery displays of crocosmias and red hot pokers in a border, or put them in a pot to add patio colour, around perhaps a burgundy cordyline. Taller types can be put at the back of a border, framed by late-flowering clematis.PERENNIAL SUNFLOWERThese helianthus are not like the traditional big-flowered annual we know and love, but they do make a statement and come back year after year, says Klein."My favourite is Lemon Queen. Its a big plant but even in a little garden, you can have a big plant for impact, that will flower into October and occasionally even further."It grows to around m tall, with coarse, deep green foliage and light yellow flowers cm wide, with pale yellow ray florets and a dark yellow central disk.CROCOSMIASAlso known as montbretia, crocosmias are one of the main features at the RHS Tatton show. They may have a reputation for being a bit invasive, but you can just pull up the cormsthey outgrow their space, she says."Id put crocosmias with any of the plants weve just mentioned. I have Crocosmia Lucer, which has just started to flower and it is taking over from big euphorbias."MISCANTHUSDont just consider colour when youre filling the gaps, because grasses come into their own in summer and beyond. "Varieties like Miscanthus Flamingo are so useful because they look good now but they will have beautul plumes in September, and then you can leave them all winter for structure," says Klein.Many of these plants can be obtained from the nurseries who attend the RHS shows, including Bluebell Cottage Gardens , Morton Nursery , Daisy Roots , Hardys Cottage Garden Plantsand Burncoose Nurseries .For more late summer gardening inspiration, visit rhs.org.uk tattonathome

title: recipe-mary-continis-cream-chicken-soup
story: Come rain or shine, the beaches were packed from morning till night and our cafes and chip shops did a roaring trade. We started at  in the morning and didnrsquot lock up until  at night once the pubs had emptied and the revellers had staggered home with a poke of chipshelliprsquosalt and sauce!rsquo Those were the days!When the weather broke and the summer storms blew in, my mother, Gertrude Di Ciacca, made huge pots of soup to serve with a roll and butter to keep them warm. All home made, tasty and nutritious.This was my favourite, very delicious and much classier than opening a tin!CREAM OF CHICKEN SOUPIngredients: ml Chicken Stock made with  breast or  thighs  legs free range chicken,  sticks celery, stalks of parsley ml full fat milk fresh bay leaf shallotg unsalted butter tablespoons plain flourSea salt and ground white pepper tablespoons thick creamFlat leaf parsley finely choppedMethod:First, make the chicken stock by simmering the chicken in ml water with the celery and parsley stalks for an hour or so.Season with sea salt and set aside.To make the soup:Place the milk, bay leaf and shallot in a saucepan, bring to a slow simmer.Take off the heat and set aside to let the flavours infuse.Make a classic bechamel sauce.Melt the butter in a saucepan and add the flour.Stir on a low heat with a wooden spoon until the mixture forms a ball.Cook on a medium heat for about  minutes to cook the flour, turning it with the spoon and taking care not to let it burn.Now strain half of the infused milk into the saucepan and stir the mixture until you get a smooth white sauce. Donrsquot worrythere are lumps at the start. These will disappear as the mix heats up.Once the mix is smooth add the rest of the strained milk.Bring back to a simmer and cook for about  minutes.Season.Now, strain the cooled chicken stock into the mixture and heat everything again to simmering, stirring to make the soup.You can do all this in a blender.Check seasoning and serve with pieces of the cooked chicken, a swirl of cream and a sprinkling of chopped parsley.

title: young-adult-book-review-take-treasure-hunt
story: What is the book about Lost Treasure Of The Emerald Eye is the first in a series of childrenrsquos books that I grew up with and adored. These are written under the name of Geronimo Stilton, the main character of these stories whorsquos perspective itrsquos told from. Geronimo is a hardworking and dedicated mouse that runs a newspaper in New Mouse City all until his sister Thea finds a treasure map and his first adventure begins. They set off to an island to find the treasure and encounter many twists and turns along the way.Who is it aimed at This series is mainly aimed at those from five to ten with another series with longer and more complex books for older readers.What was your favourite part My favourite part about this just has to be all the aspects that come into play to make it such an easy and smooth read, especially font which is fun and bright in that some key words stand out by being a dferent colour or style to highlight their importance and correspond to their meaning.What was your least favourite part Though itrsquos overall a humorous, lighthearted book at times the humour based around the theme of the world of mice and cheese could start to feel a little repetitive.Which character would you most like to meet I did find myself relating a lot to Geronimo especially with his love of writing, but it was his sister Thea who I found to be the most engaging due to her sense of adventure that forwards the plot and creates an exciting character to read about.Why should someone buy this book I wanted to share this book and the long series that follows it because of what it meant for developing my reading habits when I was younger. Being excited to read the next Geronimo Stilton novel played a big part in the advancement of my reading skills and love of books.

title: Country Life with Rosemary Goring  The joys of a cottage garden
story: In the environs of Hoolet, other than the padlocked cast-iron gates of the great houses, there is no such thing as a private garden. In one sense, everyonersquos property is off limits without permission, as it is anywhere . Unless, that is, yoursquore an apple-scrumping child ndash and which of us has never been  At this stage of le a garden with fruit trees is excellent training for a career in the SAS ndash get in, achieve mission and scarper without trace or casualties. Part of the allure of these raids, as I recall, is not just the trepidation of trespassing, but of taking forbidden fruit. Usually we gathered the unripe apples and stone-hard pears as ammunition for our long-running battles, rather than as a source of vitamin C. If kids ever clamber over the fence for our apples, theyrsquod be more than welcome. If they could also pick the crab apples and turn them into jam that would be appreciated.Many aspects of le are very dferent this summer from last, but one thing has not changed. Regardless of the lurgy, fruit is ripening fast on bushes and trees the high season of berries is upon us. One of the most vivid memories of our first August here was sitting in a friendrsquos summerhouse and suddenly seeing three folk emerging from the far end of their garden. Each was clutching a bowl heaped with jewel-like fruits, and as they passed it was aswersquod glimpsed the three Magi.A few days ago, we were invited into the same garden, to help ourselves to raspberries. It had been a day of torrential rain, with intermittent sun. The sky was darkening as we made our way between the rows, which were heavy with fat sweet rasps. When the rain began, I put up my hood, and picked on. The scent of wet leaves and trodden earth was intoxicating, a bouquet richer than a Barola. These bushes had been growing here long before our friends arrived,  years ago. They are kept company by apple and pear trees, redcurrant bushes, and plums that, when ripe, hang from the branches like ear-rings. Therersquos also a large bed of still-ripening strawberries. One year I watched a mouse, on tiptoe, nibbling a dangling berry.Irsquove rarely tasted better raspberries than the ones we collected, their flavour enhanced by the atmosphere of the garden where they grew. Being allowed access to this most beautul, out of the way corner reminds me a little of The Secret Garden. That book that made such an impression on me as a girl that I drove my parents nuts begging to be allowed to buy a derelict Victorian walled garden close by. I would climb onto the seat by the bus stop to look over its wall and plan how Irsquod clear it of weeds and shattered glass house and fill it with vegetables and flowers. Since Irsquod shown no desire to lt so much as a dandelion in our own back yard, I was told to dream on.The garden where we, and others, are invited to forage is a perfect complement to the fields and hills beyond. Flowerbeds, graceful trees and a croquet-style lawn coexist seamlessly with fruit and, previously, rows of vegetables too. When people picture the rural idyll, itrsquos often a rose-festooned house where hollyhocks run amok. Yet the true cottage garden was never chocolate-box pretty but a place where leeks and cabbages grew among primroses and poppies ndash more Mr McGregor than Vita Sackville-West. That is still the case. In one of my favourite Hoolet gardens, a formal square bed of roses encloses a profusion of succulent young lettuces, ready to lt for lunch.This is an artful nod to where all such cultivation began. Originally, humble countryside plots were essential sources of food there was no room for unproductive and time-consuming grass, or patios where clematis and wisteria rambled towards dormer windows, choking the gutters. Wholly utilitarian, they contained rectangular beds devoted to cabbages and potatoes and, weather permitting, caned trellises for fruit. These were beautul in their own way, but it was only when flowers escaped from hedgerows and colonised the margins and spaces between the plots that they gained nostalgic postcard charm.The plant collector, Major Lawrence Johnston, is responsible for redefining the cottage garden. In the early th century, when he and his mother moved into Hidcote Manor in the Cotswolds, he took the idea of a rural plot, edited its contents, and scaled it up. The result, with winding paths, artistic focal points, and teeming, colourful borders, had the appearance of being haphazard, random and accidental, when in fact it was rigorously planned. It sounds spectacular. Increasingly, though, Irsquom coming to think that outdoor spaces designed solely to please the eye are lacking in one vital ingredient: the kind you can put on a plate.Thanks in part to the generosity of neighbours, we too are starting to feed ourselves: redcurrants and blackcurrants, strawberries ndash still in relative infancy ndash rhubarb, carrots and herbs. Wersquore not in the league of those who can nurture asparagus Irsquom told it takes seven years for a first crop to appear. In fact, wersquore not in any league at all. After Alan dug up last yearrsquos potatoes, I replanted that bed with roses, honeysuckle and lavender. At one point in late spring, these new arrivals were suddenly swamped by a profusion of shaws, as the undetected, button-sized potatoes left buried in the winter sprouted into le. Following a striking display of flowers, we now have an unexpected crop of delicious spuds to keep us going for weeks. The satisfaction of filling your own larder is immense. Itrsquos at times like this that you realise keeping a cottage garden is a process of give and take.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: midge-repellents-keep-biting-beasties-bay
story: The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency: A dry oil spray.Smell: Baby talcum powder.Verdict: Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency: A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell: Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict: Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.Ingredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency: A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell: Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict: A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency: A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell: Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict: An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: herald-diary-squirrels-go-nuts-neil-oliver
story: A PROUD Neil Oliver boasts: ldquoI can make squirrels so excited, I could almost swear they understand human speech. Wersquove no idea how the popular broadcaster manages this impressive feat. Perhaps he reads to them from his book The Story of the British Isles in  Places. Though having perused the volume, we donrsquot recall a chapter dedicated to nutshellipFreudian footyRICHARD Foster, who has signed for Partick Thistle, is a special footballer. Not only is he married to rocker Amy Macdonald, the burly defender also completed a psychology degree in his spare time. We hope hersquoll make use of his qualication playing for the Jags. Even so, there are certain questions he canrsquot answer. ldquoWhy is there only one Monopolies Commission  he wonders.Basket casesWE continue comparing the world before lockdown with the present. title: letters-no-doubt-lockdown-saved-lives
story: As I wrote last week, I have been closely involved in the response to the pandemic, in my case within sport. Far from it being an exercise in stupidity those countries which responded immediately to the crisis through imposing lockdownhave come through the pandemic relatively unscathed, whilst others who delayed, including the UK, have suffered signicantly, and as we can see in the United States and Brazil, continue to suffer through their failure to introduce and sustain a coherent lockdown programme.I would be interested in knowing what Mr Adamss qualications are that allow him to make such an ill-considered sweeping statement supported by absolutely no empirical evidence whatsoever, or does he belong to the Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro school of medical wisdom That I am saddened by such remarks is because to my mind they exhibit a lack of respect for those who have lost their lives through a failure of governance and for the many more who would have died, and may still yetthe actions currently in place are not enforced rigorously a key part of which was lockdown. Such actions are not, nor have ever been, a joke.Bill Mitchell, Kyle of Lochalsh.IT was good that Robert Howiegot a lot off his chest in his letter to The Herald.Fortunately, the letter from Douglas Jardine which followed indicated why the people in Scotland should adhere to the actions recommended by FACTS and should wear a face mask at appropriate times .By doing this, we lessen our chances of becoming one of the millions affected by this global pandemic.Duncan Stirling, Cardross.ON July  Nicola Sturgeon insisted she wouldnt be rushed into dropping quarantine restrictions on airport arrivals, preferring to follow the science and her advisers. On that day, Spain declared  new cases. The very next day she dropped quarantine for most countries apart from Serbia and Spain. Spain announced  new cases that day.Yesterday, two weeks later, Spain reported a four-fold rise in new cases to , and Nicola Sturgeon dropped its quarantine restriction . Am I wrong in thinking her advisers are actually holidaymakers and opinion poll companies Allan Sutherland, Stonehaven.WITH the pandemic now under some kind of control in Scotland, would it not be best now for the First Minister to stand down from her almost daily announcements  She could let a health expert take over the daily update,it is deemed still necessary.It seems almost asshe has grown to love the spotlight and coverage and will have to be dragged screaming and kicking from the podium and cameras. An announcement in Holyrood, where she can be questioned properly, seems much more fitting for the present situation.Her daily ponticating long ago became a free, and unchallenged in any meaningful way, party political broadcast.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  So was the Russia report an attempt to taint the independence referendum
story: Itrsquos all there between the lines of yesterdayrsquos Russia Report. Though curiously, none of this Moscow gold ever found its way into my bank account. Perhaps I should head across and demand payment.At any rate, we were told by all news sources yesterday, that involvement of the Russians in the independence referendum was ldquoconfirmed by the report of the Commons Intelligence and Security Committee. The evidence lay in ldquoopen source commentary it said, which was ldquocredible.The UK Government scandalously ignored evidence of similar Russian involvement in the Brexit referendum, said MPs on the committee, because it didnrsquot want to know. Surprise, surprise.But how come the committee was so sure about Russkie meddling in the Indyref, about which the Government also apparently did not want to know  Why was the ldquoopen source commentary ldquoso compelling  After all, such commentary is just what people had been saying in published sources.There was no shortage of ldquoopen source commentary during Brexit from any number of commentators, such as the prolic Carole Cadwalladr in the Observer, who reported that senior Brexiters were in regular contact with Russian diplomats and business interests. Why did the committee disown all that The implication was that the true Indyref smoking gun was in the classied annex to yesterdayrsquos report. According to the former UK National Security Adviser, Sir Mark Lyell Grant, interviewed on BBC World At One, it was ldquowell known that the Russians were ldquoamplying social media messages during the  campaign. Well known by whom The published report refers only to claims about voting irregularities made after the  referendum and designed to discredit the result. It also referred obliquely to newspaper speculation about cybernat ldquoMcBots punting Russian propaganda.It rather looked asthe Labour and Conservative MPs on the committee were only able to agree on one thing: that the Russians were obviously all over the Scottish independence referendum and that the Government should have taken better note.According to the Labour MP, Kevan Jones, at yesterdayrsquos ISC press conference, the UK Government ignored the ldquoflashing lights from  and turned a blind eye to evidence that similar Russian ldquomeddling had occurred in the Brexit referendum in . Perhaps surprisingly, SNP MP Steward Hosie, who is also on the committee, took up the theme with alacrity. He chastised successive UK governments for not acting on known Russian involvement in the Scottish independence referendum: ldquoIt must have been clear that had they looked for similar evidence [in Brexit] it would have been extraordinarythey had not reached the same conclusions.Questioned later about this on BBC Radio Scotland, Mr Hosie said that he was only able to talk about what was in the unredacted report, not the secret annex. Thatrsquos all very well, but it leaves a nasty smell over the entire referendum campaign.I think we can all agree that the UK is ndash as the report put it ndash ldquoa top target for Russian security and intelligence services. But the activities of the IRA, the Internet Research Agency, which is assumed to be the perpetrator of these electoral dirty tricks, are almost incidental to the more serious activities of the Russian state. After all, it is widely assumed to have been conducting assassinations on UK soil using some of the most toxic agents known. This was against former KGB spies Alexander Litvinov and Sergei Skripal. These were terrorist actions and clearly a priority for the UKrsquos intelligence and security forces.But social media influencing is a rather dferent kettle of spooks. What I mainly recall from  were the widespread claims of vote-rigging and dirty tricks, not by the Kremlin but by MI. Many SNP supporters on Twitter believe the Alex Salmond sex case was orchestrated by the UK secret service.If, as the ISC committee recommended yesterday, MI spooks should now be actively investigating and judging social media posts during election campaigns, then yet more mistrust and paranoia will assuredly be the result. Why so sure  Because they are already doing this.It was revealed in  that the Institute for Statecraft, and its protege the Integrity Initiative, funded by the UK Foreign Office, was already battling Vladimir Putinrsquos social media meddling from the improbable location of a disused mill in Fe. The Integrity Initiative is all about countering ldquodisinformation and malign influence from Russia, which increasingly originates online.However, these hapless hacktivists strayed disastrously into domestic politics. The Integrity Initiative had to apologise to the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, for retweeting messages suggesting that he was one of Mr Putinrsquos ldquouseful idiots. Itrsquos not clear which of the institutersquos , tweets were alleging this, but we can guess.Ms Cadwalladr had claimed in  that senior members of the Labour Party including Jeremy Corbynrsquos communications director, Seumas Milne, were Russian patsies. ldquoMilnersquos support of Russia is like Faragersquos, she tweeted in December . ldquoTherersquos nothing hidden. Itrsquos completely overt.This is the problem with trying to fight a propaganda war on social media. Even more than conventional spying it is a hall of mirrors. Paranoia feeds paranoia. In calling for the intelligence services to start investigating election campaigns, the ISC committee is asking for something the spooks dearly want to avoid.Take Labourrsquos ldquoNHS for sale dossier, which became a major story in the  General Election campaign. This first appeared on the Reddit website. That websitersquos own security analysts claimed that, while the documents on Britainrsquos trade negotiations with the US were genuine, they were put into the public domain by Russian sources.Do we seriously want MI judging the veracity and origins of every election issue  Arguably, yesterdayrsquos ISC report was itself an exercise in political propaganda serving to taint the  referendum with Russian involvement. Yet there is precisely no evidence, compelling or otherwise, that this had any impact on the result. Keep spooks out of politics.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: bureaucracy-furlough-gratitude
story: The Daily MailRichard Littlejohn points out a sign spotted at the municipal tennis courts in Alexandra Gardens, Windsor, Berks, and bearing the seals of Public Health England and Windsor and Maidenhead council - lsquoOnly handle your own balls.rsquoldquoWhen I stopped laughing, it occurred to me that this might be an elaborate spoof, he said. ldquoBut given that it was posted above the official Lawn Tennis Association guidance on how to play tennis safely under social distancing regulations, it certainly has the ring of authenticity about it.He said PHE made a lsquolucrative career out of badgering and nannying usrsquo, especially during the summer.ldquoPast initiatives have included instructing us to stay indoors and draw the curtains whenever the sun shines banning supermarkets from selling daffodils alongside fruit and veg, just in case Chinese shoppers mistake them for spring onions, he said.He said those in charge of PHE had failed to prepare for a pandemic of any kind - the one proper job they were set up for in the first place.ldquoIt has now been revealed that theyrsquove also exaggerated the number of deaths caused by Covid, something Irsquove suspected all along, he said. ldquoEven our hapless Health Secretary Matt Hancock has tumbled the scam and ordered an urgent investigation.He said anyone who had Covid- and recovers, but dies due to something  was included in the figures.ldquoIt would explain the inflated daily body count read out robotically until recently, like the football results, he added. ldquoWhile no one disputes the magnicent way in which frontline NHS staff responded to the emergency, the pandemic has exposed the dysal, complacent bureaucracy behind the scenes.Clare McNeil, associate director at IPPR and head of its Future Welfare State programme, said forecasts predict . million job losses when furlough ends.ldquoHowever, all sides of the political debate seem to have conceded that the flagship job retention scheme will have to end soon for most businesses, she said. ldquoButwe look abroad at countries like Germany, France and Switzerland, mass unemployment and job destruction on such a scale is not seen as a price worth paying in a recession. Instead, state-subsidised ldquoshort-time working schemes kick in across the economy, so that firms cut fewer jobs and employ more people, evensome are on shorter hours.She argued this was in stark contrast to the UKrsquos lsquoall or nothing job shedding.rsquoShe said France, Germany and Finland were keeping their job retention schemes until next spring.ldquoHelping more people to stay in work by extending the new ldquoflexible furlough scheme here could have a hugely positive impact on peoplersquos mental health, with even one day of work a week found to make a genuine contribution to wellbeing, she said. ldquoWe urgently need progressive ideas that can meet the scale of the challenge ahead. In the months ahead, ldquocut hours not people should be our mantra for this unemployment crisis.The Leo McKinstry said no group of workers deserved a pay rise more than the public sector frontline employees.ldquoIn the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis the case for an increase above inflation is unanswerable, he said. ldquoDuring the long, bleak months when the emergency was at its peak tThey helped to keep the country going through their dedication and sense of service. Without their selfless commitment our civic infrastructure could have broken down and the disease spread like wildfire.He said the announcement of a pay rise for one million workers was a tangible expression of gratitude for all they had done.ldquoCivil servants get a lot of stick, but in the hour of emergency they met the challenge, as reflected in the success of the universal credit benefits system and the Treasuryrsquos vast business support scheme. despite unprecedented demands, he added. ldquoAfter these fully justied awards, the next task is to see that the private sector acts in the same fashion.ldquoKey workers here, like care-home staff, lorry drivers and retail assistants, also played their part and deserve recognition.

title: pms-year-long-time-politics
story: One would prefer to hand it over in person when he visits Scotland today, but his itinerary, as usual, is being kept under wraps until the last minute. Police clearly fear a large crowd of admirers will turn up, breaking Covid- guidelines. It would be like Elvis when he passed through Prestwick, but with a blimpish old Etonian in place of a rock and roll prince.Can it really be a year since Mr Johnson stood in a sun-dappled Downing Street and, with a mob of bellowing well-wishers outside the gates, promised to confound ldquothe doubters, the doomsters, the gloomsters who said he would not get Brexit done He also promised to make the streets safer, ensure no-one had to wait weeks to see a GP, and tackle the crisis in social care. ldquoNever mind the backstop, said the new Prime Minister using the jargon of the time, ldquothe buck stops here.He certainly tried to fulfil many of those pledges, albeit in unconventional ways. The streets were safer because they were empty. No-one could see a GP because surgeries were closed. As for social care, it had a whole other crisis to worry about. The story of Mr Johnsonrsquos first year in power is inescapably the story of Covid-. Everything  is secondary, even Brexit, crucial as its success, or otherwise, is to the future of the country. Any judgment on his first year in office is necessarily a verdict on how he dealt with the virus crisis.: Remainers need to move on says PMThough Mr Johnson would prefer to wait for the official inquiry, public opinion is way ahead of him. In a poll last week for the Sun on Sunday,  per cent of respondents thought he was doing well in his job, compared to % for Chancellor Rishi Sunak and % for the newly installed Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer.The new Commons double act of Johnson and Starmer was in action again yesterday at the last PMQs before the summer recess. These contests have settled down to a familiar routine in which prime ministerial bluster meets lawyerly formality. Neither man will be truly tested until the Commons, like everything , is back to normal, or the ldquonew normal, whatever and whenever that might be.If there is one word which sums up Mr Johnsonrsquos response to the crisis it is ldquoslow. Slow to impose a lockdown. Slow to build up testing capacity. Slow in making sure there was enough personal protective equipment for the front line staff who needed it desperately. Slow to pick up on the crisis in care homes.Since the PM, like the rest of us, was new to the crisis he was given an enormous amount of leeway. Normal business from opposition parties was suspended. The media were onside. He had been an unlucky premier, dreadfully so, but what was political ill fortune when so many people were losing loved ones  Then he fell ill, eventually ending up in intensive care. The shock, and the get well soon messages, were genuine.Whatever goodwill he built up was soon squandered by his refusal to sack his chief aide, Dominic Cummings, for driving to Durham, and beyond, during lockdown. He failed that test of leadership, just as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon neglected to show the door immediately to her chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, on learning of her double lockdown breach. On his way into Number , Mr Johnson said politicians should never forget that the people are the bosses. Well, the people wanted Mr Cummings gone, yet he remains.As for the rest of Mr Johnsonrsquos first year, it was a mixed bag. The proroguing of Parliament and the subsequent defeat in the Supreme Court would be a stain on any PMrsquos reputation.The General Election that followed was a triumph for the party, with hitherto-Labour seats falling to the Conservatives. How much that was due to votersrsquo impatience over Brexit, and how much to then Labour leader Jeremy Corbynrsquos general uselessness, depends on the observer.: Labour will pay damages to whistleblowersThen we come to Scotland, which stands in the same place it did when Mr Johnson became Prime Minister ndash stuck in the middle between the status quo and independence. Scotland has not appeared to figure much in the PMrsquos calculations this past year, though he has had other things on his mind. That is about to change we are told, hence his visit to Scotland today.Thereafter Scotland is to be love bombed by Downing Street, with ministers encouraged to follow the PM north to talk up the benefits of the Union, particularly in the current crisis.This, Mr Johnson believes, will tackle increasing support for independence in the polls and drive it downwards, just in time for the next Scottish Parliament elections. That is the theory, in any case.The reality may be very dferent. Telling Scotland how much better off it is in the Union by talking up how much money has flowed from Westminster suggests those billions are in the form of grants and do not have to be repaid. In fact, Scottish taxpayers, in common with taxpayers in the rest of the UK, will be the ones eventually paying the bills Mr Johnson is running up. To adapt a phrase from a former Chancellor, we are all in this mess together.Mention of George Osborne brings us to the reason Mr Johnson will get in and out of Scotland today ashis trousers were on fire. When it comes to the Conservatives, Scotlandrsquos memory goes back much further than a year. In the manner of Back to the Future, shall we turn the clock  years to the Coalition Government and the start of austerity  Or -plus years to Mrs Thatcher and all that came after  Earlier Scotlandrsquos problem with the Conservatives has nothing to do with not understanding them. It is that we understand them only too well.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.#

title: opinion-neil-mackay-buckle-citizens-scottish-politics-enter-new-world-crazy
story: Butyou think the last few years have been crazy, you ainrsquot seen nothing yet. This week has given a good example of just how unhinged Scottish politics is about to become. Letrsquos take the Russia Report. At heart, it shows the Tory government is utterly unfit for power. Itrsquos incapable of defending the UK. Not only that but the party is floating on a sea of Russian roubles. Westminster has lain down and let Russian oligarchs use it as a doormat to Britain where they can launder dirty money.Then we come to Brexit. In the reportrsquos wake, we now know the UK Government actively avoided looking at any evidence that Russia interfered in the vote. Thatrsquos not just gob-smacking ndash itrsquos so egregious it would dislocate your entire jaw. What on Earth was the reportrsquos intentionnot to investigate Russian meddling over Europe  It is the "Russia" report after all. The giveaway is in the name. What  was it going to investigate  Putinrsquos latest bare-chested poses for the Kremlin Christmas calendar The fish in my fish-tank know Russia had its sticky spooky fingers all over Brexit, particularly when it came to online manipulation and disinformation.The report shows the UK Government to be a cabinet of liars ndash or rather idiots who are bad liars, and think wersquore too stupid to see their lies. Actually, make that lying idiots whorsquod let a hostile foreign power meddle with UK democracy as long as it served its own petty party political ambitions, and helped grters and mountebanks like Boris Johnson get power.Herersquos where the Russia report plays into the growing craziness of Scottish politics, though: the big leak to the press before the publication of the report was that Russia had interfered in the independence referendum. Forget Brexit, put the weight of the report on to Scotland ndash that was clearly Downing Streetrsquos strategy.Evidently, most rational and informed folk accept Russia was trying it on when it came to the  referendum. Why wouldnrsquot it be  But to focus on interference in Scotland and not look into Brexit is nothing but straight up manipulation of intelligence and security.This all shows what way the wind is blowing. With a new Tory unit set up to fight independence, rest assured there will be more stupid dirty tricks. Only a dummy would think otherwise. That means Scottish politics is going to get weird. Downing Street isnrsquot scared to use any cynical ploy.But the craziness isnrsquot all on one side. Far from it. While the independence movement could easily bask in the lunacy of London, saying "see, this is what we want to save you from", some elements of the nationalist fringe have decided to don a crazy suit themselves. Support for independence is now the majority position and the SNP is storming the polls as the public responds to coronavirus ndash but why rest on good fortune when you could trash everything Why not hold a rally outside Holyrood, with figures like former SNP MSP George Kerevan, and tell the world that the Yes movement ldquocannot be patient any longer. Why not have speakers say that itrsquos time to ldquostart getting angry  Thatrsquos not going to put off potential Yes voters, surely Why not call for Union Street in Aberdeen to be renamed Independent Street  That doesnrsquot look daft.Why not have an organiser of the nationalist marching group All Under One Banner say that ldquomanaging Covid should run parallel with fighting for independence  Thatrsquos the same marching group where signs denouncing "Tory scum" unfurl at rallies. A tactic designed to win over soft unionist voters, Irsquom sure.Why not start talking about Scottish "freedom"  Free Scotland from what, actually, is my question  I support independence and itrsquos not because therersquos some colonial army of English occupation in Peebles, itrsquos because I think Scotland can do better on its own than it currently fairs as part of the Westminster system.But it doesnrsquot stop there. Why not start a new political party and use it to drive a wedge between the independence movement  And why not have that new political party, Alliance for Independence, linked to the craziest fringe of the entire Yes movement  A regional AFI organiser was behind the much denounced protest at the border where Yes supporters wore hazmat suits and shouted ldquoplague carriers at visitors crossing from the south.That ought to work. If therersquos anything likely to reach out to a hesitant voter, then this must surely be it. And just for good measure, why not throw Tommy Sheridan into the mix and make sure hersquos involved in this brave new political party too.Done deal. Therersquos no way independence is going to risk any damage from that catalogue of tactical brilliance.The bottom line is this: Boris Johnsonrsquos government is dangerous. It would trash anything and everything for the sake of one objective: raw power. So how is this dangerous government likely to treat Scotland as the independence debate intensies in the coming months  Get ready for a dirty fight, thatrsquos all I can say.Meanwhile in the indy corner, the wild, conspiratorial base is getting out of control, and risks damaging the entire Yes movement with its absurd, juvenile antics. The Yes movement has to get itself in order and keep the extremists in their box. Politics cannot be a matter of "crazy versus crazy". The independence movement will only win with reason, openness and persuasion. Anything  is mere posturing, designed to serve the posturer rather than the country or the ideal.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: split-emerges-new-scottish-independence-party-second-referendum
story: The Alliance for Independence , which filed registration papers with the Electoral Commission yesterday, says one of its key goals isa second independence referendum.However one of its most
