The club football and hurling championships will go ahead as planned, it has been confirmed. Speculation was mounting over the feasibility of the club championships at the weekend, after  clubs suspended their senior activities following positive cases of Covid-. Banagher and Craigbane acted first, on Thursday night, before they were joined by Ardmore, Limavady, Drumsurn, Magilligan, Glack, Foreglen, Claudy and Drum followed suit. Drum have extended their cessation of activities until Monday, July . “This is a matter for the organising committee, in this instance Derry GAA, to manage as they see fit,” said Alan Milton, the GAAs Director of Communications, while also saying it was discussed with counties on a conference call last week. googletag.cmd.push The GAA has ed to games activity on the principle of opt-in added Declan Woods, Ulster GAAs PRO. “Given the uncertainties that exist around Covid-, each county has been asked to draft Competition Rules to deal with potential scenarios.” Derry have indicated that their championships, starting with Saturdays hurling clash of Banagher and Coleraine will go ahead. Games will he played as scheduled,” a Derry board spokesperson told the County Derry Post. With no movement away from the scheduled date anda club cannot fulfill a fixture due to issues surrounding Covid-, the game will be awarded to the opposition team without any further penalty being imposed. googletag.cmd.push Of the  clubs who stood down at the weekend, Banagher were advised one of their members has been confirmed as positive for the virus. It is understood to be a player and the club moved by insisting all their players get tested. “We resume training on Wednesday night,” outlined senior hurling manager John ODwyer. “Only players who come back with a negative test will be permitted to train or to play in Saturdays game with Coleraine.” The former Derry camogie manager, who won back to back Ulster titles with the countys hurlers, feels the GAA should pull the pin on the season. “For the sake of five games, they should have forgot about it and started again in January. For us in Banagher, we did everything according to plan and it takes a lot of effort to go through with the procedures. “For us, there is just not enough gain. If I wasnt the manager, I would be nowhere near it. Someone at a higher level shouldve made the decision to call off the season.” Grab this weeks County Derry Post for previews of this weekends hurling games. RELATEDThis weeks fixtures. A cluster of Covid- cases have been traced to a private or residential setting in a County Derry town, says the Public Health Agency . In a statement, they said: Testing and contact tracing is being conducted to identy people who may be potentially affected to help prevent any further spread. With lockdown restrictions being eased this type of occurrence is to be expected, which is why the Test, Trace and Protect programme is in place. At present anyone who tests positive for COVID- in Northern Ireland will be contacted by the contact tracing team to be given advice on what to do about managing symptoms and of the need to self-isolate to prevent any wider spread of the virus. googletag.cmd.push They will also be asked who they have been in contact with so that we can follow up with those iniduals to give them advice to help prevent the further spread of infection. Contact tracing is an established method to help prevent the further spread of infections such as COVID-, and we are using this approach to target potential clusters which could spark new outbreaks. Limavady councillor, James McCorkell, appealed for people not to panic, and to co-operate with the contact tracing teamthey are contacted. This highlights the fact that we are by no means over this troubling time and people must take this serious when out and about, he said. googletag.cmd.push I would ask that people dont panic - the Test Trace  Protect system is there to help identy these pockets that will inevitably flare up whilst we continue to go through this pandemic. I would appeal for people to cooperate with the Contact Tracing Team, should they be contacted, as this will help get any clusters under control on the area. Please also ensure you know the symptoms of covid- and take every precaution when out and about to social distance and follow at the guidance the Government has asked us to follow. If the team identies a potential cluster or outbreak this will be reported through the PHA’s normal outbreak management channels and the appropriate infection control advice actions carried out. PHA will continue to monitor all cases of COVID-, look for trends and linked cases and where we need to advise or inform the public of any increased risk to public health we will do so in a timely manner. We will not comment on inidual cases as this could lead to people being identied and deter others with symptoms coming forward to be tested. We would ask everyone to be mindful of this risk. This virus has the potential to make its presence felt in any district. Everyone should act on the basis that it might potentially be in their neighbourhood right now. That’s why following the public health advice on regular hand washing and maintaining a social distance of two metres remains vitally important. We must be aware that COVID- is still a threat and we need everyone to play their part in helping to stop the virus spreading.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. There has been a combined increase of  positive Covid- cases across County Derry’s council areas since the PHA identied a ‘cluster’ in the Limavady area last week. Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council, where Limavady is situated, experienced the largest surge in cases, with an extra  since last Wednesday. A mobile testing unit, situated on the Greystone Road, was deployed to the area in response to the cluster. Only one more case was recorded in the Mid Ulster area, but Derry and Strabane saw fourteen new cases, bringing its total to . Ten local GAA clubs suspended activities as a precautionary measure in response to the cluster, with only St Mary’s GAC, Banagher, confirming a positive case within their members. googletag.cmd.push A club spokesperson said: “All relevant people have been contacted and the Public Health Agency will contact any club memberthey feel there is a concern. “We will keep you up to date of any information received from them. “The GAA has advised the club to continue as normal, although we have decided to cancel all underage training until further notice.” A shop in Claudy, part of the Derry and Strabane district, has also confirmed a member of its staff is currently in isolation after testing positive for Covid-. In a statement, posted online, Centra Claudy said other members of staff have volunteered for testing. googletag.cmd.push “Whilst we do have one staff member who has tested positive for Covid- they are in isolation since they had the test and are following public health advice,” they said. “The public health authority did not contact any of our other staff for testing via track  trace although some have volunteered for testing and all results to date have ed negative. “We can assure you that we have been following very strict Covid guidelines since we entered this pandemic in March. “Our staff have worked tirelessly to provide a service for the local area, and we have appreciated the support  patience from our community in following guidelines when shopping.” A ‘local lockdown’ have been enforced in Leicester, England, after a surge in positive cases, and the Department of Health said the strategy would be ‘considered’ in Northern Ireland. “With lockdown restrictions being eased it is likely that we will see clusters and outbreaks of Covid-,” a DoH spokesperson said. “In circumstances where the number of cases continues to increase a range of measures will be considered, including the introduction of local lockdownsnecessary and depending on the circumstances as they arise.” Sinn Feacutein MLA Caoimhe Archibald. East Derry MLA, Caoimhe Archibald, has urged people not to panic, saying the figures were proof the Test, Trace and Protect system was working. “It is concerning that a cluster has been identied, first and foremost for those iniduals who are affected,” she said. “Hopefully no one is suffering from serious symptoms and will recover quickly, but there is a general concern there in the local community and that’s understandable. “We don’t want people to be alarmed. We have seen the test, trace and isolate system in place, and we can see how that is working. “The cases have been identied and the process is rolling out. That is critical to containing the virus and we see those procedures working effectively. “It’s a timely reminder to us all that we can’t become complacent, that we do need to remain vigilant and practise public health guidance in terms of social distancing, good hygiene and cough etiquette.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Traffic disruption is to be expected in Kilrea from next week as a three-week period of resurfacing and associated works gets underway. Bridge Street in the town and the Bann Road will be closed from the Diamond Roundabout to the junction with the Ballymaconnelly Road. Traffic will be erted through Portglenone via the Moneygran Road, a route that is expected to result in a --minute delay to motorists’ journeys.  Local councillor, Sean Bateson, welcomed the beginning of the work, while acknowledging the disruption it will cause. “Road issues have been an ongoing problem in Bridge Street for some time now and, as such, the full resurfacing of the street as far as the mph on the Bann Road is good news,” he said. googletag.cmd.push “Indeed, after extensive lobbying to DFI road service we managed to get the works pulled forward for the worst part of the street back in March. “The full resurfacing from the th July to the st August will inevitably cause some disruption to the town but I ask locals to bear with the works please as they are being done. “It will be great for the street and the wider town of Kilrea once completed.” The much-needed work will take place from Monday, July  at .am, until Saturday, August  at .pm, with the road closure operating every day. Three Mid Ulster District Council Arts facilities this coming weekend in recognition of the district’s frontline workers’ efforts during the Covid- pandemic. The Bridewell, Magherafelt, Ranfurly House, Dungannon and The Burnavon in Cookstown will light up red and white, the Council colours, over the weekend Friday  to Sunday  July. It comes after a motion, proposed by Deputy Chair, Meta Graham, at the council’s monthly meeting, received unanimous support. Cllr Graham wanted to publicly convey the council’s thanks to the workers who worked tirelessly outside the spotlight during the pandemic. “We all clapped deservedly week after week for our remarkable and brave NHS to show our support and to thank them for the sacrices they made during this dficult time,” she said. googletag.cmd.push “However, I think our thanks and appreciation need to be extended further to include all of those who are sometimes overlooked and quite often taken for granted. Cllr Meta Graham proposed the motion. “We all need to pause and remember that while we may not have had everything we wanted during this crisis, thanks to the work of these dedicated workers, we certainly had everything we needed. “This gesture is a small token of our gratitude, appreciation and thanks to all those who have so selflessly kept Mid Ulster going over the last  months, often at considerable risk to themselves. We owe you all a great debt.” googletag.cmd.push Farmers, factory workers, delivery drivers, lorry drivers, postal workers, retail workers, the PSNI, the NIFRS, small local shops, council staff, volunteers and community groups were among those included by Cllr Graham.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The priest at the funeral of popular young Portstewart man, Michael McQuillan, told mourners that his ability to ‘gather people around him’ brought out love in so many people. The -year-old passed away at his family home in the seaside town on Saturday night, causing widespread shock throughout the community. Fr Ciaran Dallat, who has known the McQuillan family for a number of years, told the congregation to treasure their memories of the popular young man. “You can rejoice in the  years that Michael has been with us,” he said. “Smicko’, for the lads over there, and wee Michael for most of his family, had a great way of gathering people around him. googletag.cmd.push “I know, in the midst of the fun, there was devilment, but wasn’t that what you liked about him  You didn’t know what was coming next, sometimes. “Each of you have your own stories and I’m sure most of the memories you had were good, but suddenly, in the space of a few days, they have become treasured.” Michael in action for his club, Eoghan Rua. Michael was a dual player for local GAA club Eoghan Rua, who have organised a memory box full of photographs and notes to be presented to his family. Fr Dallat said the support of the GAA community had ‘meant so much’ to Michael’s family. googletag.cmd.push “It’s obvious there just how much sport, and the lads and lassies involved, meant to him,” he said. “It meant so much to Margaret, Paul and Joseph this week, just to have them standing alongside them. “That’s what they were doing out there, just standing alongside people who they love and care for and saying, ‘we don’t know what to do here, but we’re going to stand alongside you anyway’. “That, in itself, is beautul, and it’s because Michael gathered people around him.” Michael’s ability to gather people around him formed a central part of Fr Dallat’s homily, and he spoke of how he was always able to make those around him feel ‘important’. “We have been blessed. It has been a joy to know him,” he told the congregation. “You only had to pass through the house over the last few days to see the love that this wee man has engendered in the time he has been with us. Eoghan Rua have arranged for a memory box to be presented to Michaels family. “Michael had some experience as a classroom assistant in Downpatrick, and the children loved him. He had an ability with children to gather them around and make them feel important. “The same is true here in Portstewart. It wasn’t only his peers he knew how to take care of and bring into the centre of the craic, but that was a gt as well.” Fr Dallat concluded by asking those who loved him to remember Michael for the joy he brought to others. “There are photographs and there are memories, but unfortunately, he won’t bound back into the house once more, looking for money to put petrol in the car for the next bit of the journey,” he said. “He was a man, who though small in stature, always dreamed big. He was someone who drew the love out of others. “Whatever name you have known him by, think for a moment about your favourite memory and thank God for the smile he has put on your face and for the love he has put in your heart.”   --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A local councillor is concerned at the large number of young people gathering at a former school site in Derry. SDLP Councillor Shauna Cusack said young people have been holding parties and lighting fires at the former Foyle College site at Northland Road. Cllr Cusack said: This is a large site which unfortunately is very easily accessed. It is due to be the site for the new Ardnashee school with an estimated date of Spring  for the works to commence. We all know what happened with the old building when it had to be demolished last year following an arson attack and it seems the site has again become a magnet for anti social behaviour. googletag.cmd.push Cllr Cusack said that in recent weekslocal residents have reported large numbers of youths trying to access the site with drink. They have set up palettes for seating within the trees at the periphery of the site and can be heard partying into the early hours causing sleepless nights for the residents. The PSNI and the Council Community Safety Wardens have been in attendance and have witnessed evidence of drug taking also. This latest incident, which we all feared shows how these gatherings can escalate and get out of control engendering both themselves, others and surrounding property. I have been speaking with the authorities and directly with the Education Authority at the end of last week who had committed to removing materials and investigate private security to monitor the private site. googletag.cmd.push Meanwhile, I would ask parents and the public to play their part and either talk to your child about this area or report any trespass you see. While the obvious activities of underage drinking, drugs and now arson are very worrying we cannot forget the silent killer of Covid being transmitted when unmonitored crowds gather. The Bridewell building in Magherafelt is to get a temporary makeover. Three Mid Ulster District Council arts facilities will be lit up this weekend in recognition of the district’s frontline workers’ efforts during the Covid- pandemic. The Bridewell, Magherafelt, Ranfurly House, Dungannon and The Burnavon in Cookstown will light up red and white, the council colours, over the weekend. It comes after a motion, proposed by Deputy Chair, Meta Graham, at the council’s monthly meeting, received unanimous support. Cllr Graham wanted to publicly convey the council’s thanks to the workers who worked tirelessly outside the spotlight during the pandemic. “We all clapped deservedly week after week for our remarkable and brave NHS to show our support and to thank them for the sacrices they made during this dficult time,” she said. googletag.cmd.push “However, I think our thanks and appreciation need to be extended further to include all of those who are sometimes overlooked and quite often taken for granted. “We all need to pause and remember that while we may not have had everything we wanted during this crisis, thanks to the work of these dedicated workers, we certainly had everything we needed. “This gesture is a small token of our gratitude, appreciation and thanks to all those who have so selflessly kept Mid Ulster going over the last  months, often at considerable risk to themselves. We owe you all a great debt.” googletag.cmd.push Farmers, factory workers, delivery drivers, lorry drivers, postal workers, retail workers, the PSNI, the NIFRS, small local shops, council staff, volunteers and community groups were among those included by Cllr Graham.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Derry Citys glamour friendly game with Glasgow Celtic has been cancelled as the FAI pulled the plug on the clubs hopes of flying to Scotland to face Neil Lennons champions at the weekend. A spokesperson for the club confirmed the news last night after a day of uncertainly regarding the potential fixture. Originally scheduled to face League of Ireland champions Dundalk, Celtic were expecting to welcome the Lilywhites to Celtic Park, but quarantine restrictions ended their hopes of playing the game with anyone coming into the Republic from the UK having to self isolate for  days. With the League of Ireland set to start next Friday, that would have been impossible for the champions. googletag.cmd.push That opened the door for Derry City to step into the glamour friendly, with reports suggesting that former Celtic and City star Paddy McCourt was heavily involved in organising the game. The hope was that, as Derry City would only be travelling to another part of the UK from Northern Ireland, they are not bound by the same restrictions. That hope continued into yesterday, with the club hoping to finalise arrangements for the game, but they were dashed by the FAI last night. With City set to travel to Dublin to face St. Patricks Athletic, just eight days after the proposed game in Scotland, the same -day rule which scuppered Dundalks plans, also appear to have stopped Derry, despite technically being in the UK. googletag.cmd.push Instead of Celtic, City hope to finalise their pre-season plans with a game against Northwest neighbours Finn Harps behind closed doors at the Brandywell tomorrow night. Declan Devines men faced Cltonville in midweek and drew -, with the City boss running his eye over three new trialists. The Candystyripes face Sligo Rovers in the resumption of the league season next Friday. Celtic, meanwhile, who now wont have Irish opposition this weekend, finished off their mini tour of France with a - defeat at French giants Paris St-German, with superstars Kylian Mbappe and Neymar both on the scoresheet in the Parc des Princes encounter.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: ‘Leave us alone’ plea to vandals
story: DOWNPATRICK and County Down Railway officials have appealed to young people to ldquostop trying to destroy the place following a series of recent incidents.Vandals have targeted the award-winning heritage railway on three occasions, the incidents coming after officials warned that the attraction may not reopen this year as a result a cash crisis.Officials say the main gates at the railwayrsquos base at Market Street were forced open, while a fence at the Inch Abbey station was smashed.In addition, damage was caused to the lsquoLooprsquo . Fortunately, a fire, believed to have spread to undergrowth after an attempt was made to set a speed restriction sign alight, did not develop into a large blaze.The volunteers who run the railway mdash who have launched an urgent appeal to raise pound, mdash are particularly concerned about an attempt to force open the main gates they discovered empty beer cans. First aid boxes at the station were also raided for bandages.Damage at the Loop  was discovered during a recent shunt to test rolling stock and carry out essential track maintenance, with the exercise taking place while visitors were banned from the railway due to lockdown restrictions.Railway officials have reported the incidents to police and have appealed to anyone who can assist officers with their enquiries to come forward.The recent incidents come after the coronavirus lockdown had a massive hit on the railwayrsquos finances.In an online post, officials appealed to young people to ldquoleavethem alone and stop trying to destroy the place, also asking parents do they know where their children are and what they are doing.The hard-working volunteers say they have enough on their plate without having to ldquosort out other peoplersquos mess, expressing concern about people walking along the railway lines which they are not allowed to do.Officials say the ldquostupidity of others is the reason why they hope the local community will support their fundraising appeal to help pay for better security as a bid for financial help from the Northern Ireland Executive proved unsuccessful.A recent bid for support from the Department of Communitiesrsquo Covid- Charities Fund to cover costs racked up to maintain the business which has been mothballed due to lockdown restrictions was unsuccessful.Officials fear that the railway will also miss out on securing a slice of a poundm fund for business start-ups and tourist attraction investment which was announced recently.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner recently wrote an open letter highlighting the railwayrsquos plight and its reluctance to ask for help in the current financial climate.He said coronavirus restrictions have had a ldquodevastating impact on the railwayrsquos operations and its restoration work.Mr Gardiner said the railway was likely to remain closed for the remainder of the year due to the restrictions around Covid-.He said that with no income for the rest of the year, the railway faced ldquomajor challenges.Mr Gardiner said given that the railwayrsquos final attempts at securing Covid- support funding from Stormont failed, it had reluctantly turned to its members and supporters to ask for help.He added: ldquoWe need to raise at least pound, this year just to keep the railway in a good condition and make some progress with essential projects.To date, the railwayrsquos appeal has raised pound,, with anyone interested in making a donation asked to visit www.facebook donate   or text RAIL plus the amount to  or visit www.downrail appeal.prettyPhoto

title: Aarin’s lockdown farm project
story: A DOWNPATRICK boy has been enjoying lsquoThe Good Lersquo during the Covid- lockdown.Twelve year-old Aarin Rea has spent the past four months developing a miniature farm, complete with chickens, ducks, doves and even peacocks, in the garden of his Knochnashinna home.Hersquos also growing fruit and vegetables in his allotment and specially built greenhouse, and hersquos also planted apple trees.His family and neighbours will soon be able to share in an abundance of potatoes, cabbages, lettuces, carrots, scallions, broad beans, tomatoes, strawberries and apples, as well as a supply of fresh eggs.Aarinrsquos mum, Karin, says the miniature farm has helped bring the community together during the isolation of lockdown and has lted everyonersquos spirits.ldquoItrsquos all everyone has been talking about lately, she said. ldquoThey are always enquiring as to how the farm is coming along and Aarin couldnrsquot be any prouder at whathe has achieved over the last few months.ldquoAarin has been eager to get out every day to his little farm while he has been off school. He spent the good weather tending and watering his fruit vegetables both in the allotment and in the greenhouse, which his father, Anthony, built for him.Aarin is the proud owner of peacock chicks, which were hatched thanks to a tip from his grandfather, Leslie Rea, who told him to put golf balls underneath the peacocks to encourage them to lay eggs.Aarin, has since given his poultry flock some pretty ingenious names, and he now considers his ducks, James Pond and Quacky Chan, among some of his best friends.Then there are his favourite hens, Henner Lopez, Princess Laya and Fluffy, who are very happy to the strutting around.The newest arrivals are two doves, Holy and Spirit, which are housed in a newly-built dovecote and a turkey chick.However, Aarinrsquos favourite animal is his beloved Jack Russell, Lottie.Aarinrsquos farming skills have come a long way since be began growing potatoes in tubs.ldquoI sell my duck eggs to elderly neighbours who adore their distinct flavour. Our next door neighbour, Tommy Armour, is always giving me little bits of advice to help bring the brood along. Recently, it seems to be turning out to more of a community effort to be honest, he said.ldquoAt the beginning of lockdown I missed all my friends, but the farm helped keep me busy.ldquoI wouldnrsquot be a great lover of completing schoolwork at home. I much prefer spending my time tending to my fruit and vegetables and caring for my new chicks.ldquoSometime my little sister, Grace, helps me. She is nine years old and is learning a lot more about farming than I ever thought she would.Aarin added: ldquoI thought the good weather during lockdown helped my vegetables grow. The heat certainly helped. I had to water them every day but I donrsquot need to as much since the weather turned bad..prettyPhoto

title: Ambulance staff receive praise for work in lockdown
story: HEALTH campaigners have this week praised the excellent work of ambulance staff during the coronavirus pandemic.The tribute from the Down Community Health Committee comes after senior ambulance chiefs warned that response times in the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area and across the province could be delayed as coronavirus lockdown restrictions continue to ease.Ambulance Service officials have revealed that as as normality resumes, the organisation is facing ldquoincreased challenges in maintaining planned levels of cover and that the focus will be on the most serious cases.The anticipated delayed response times is being blamed on several factors, including increased activity levels without a rise in staff numbers.In addition, ambulance officials say almost one fth of its frontline staff are absent from work due to ordinary sickness or reasons related to Covid-.The Ambulance Service said longer term trends had seen demand for services rise in recent years without an accompanying increase in staff numbers, with a recent independent capacity review identying the need for  extra staff.Senior officials said the organisationrsquos challenges had been compounded by a ldquototally unacceptable increase in assaults on staff, many of whom were then forced to take time off work to recover.Ambulance Service chief executive Michael Bloomfield appealed for support from public representatives and the community to ensure that ambulances remain available to respond to le-threatening emergencies.ldquoI appreciate the genuine concern of community and political representatives when informed of shortages in a particular area, he said.ldquoHowever, I would like to reassure all stakeholders that we will continue to manage our available resources in a way which best serves the interests of patients and staff.Mr Bloomfield said members of the public also have their part to play.ldquoWe still receive too many calls for which options other than calling  are available, he said. ldquoWe would ask that people only consider calling  for real emergencies while, at the same time, advising people not to delay in the case of a real emergency.Health campaigners have praised both ambulance personnel for their work during dficult times and the excellent work done by other healthcare workers, support staff and members of the voluntary sector and private contractors.They say it is widely recognised that the Ambulance Trust has been a victim of ldquoserious under investment over a period of many years.ldquoIt is most important that the business case intended to secure essential investment referred to by Mr Bloomfield should be actioned swtly, stated campaigners.ldquoThere has been widespread dissatisfaction over a period of many years with ambulance response times generally and that to local communities in particular.The health committee has called for urgent steps to be taken by the organisationrsquos management to ensure that there is equality of access to services for all residents within the catchment area of the Ambulance Trust, whether they are urban dwellers or rural citizens.ldquoHealth inequalities are completely unacceptable and must be addressed in short, medium and long-term planning by the Trust and the Department of Health, the statement continues.ldquoTop priority must be given by the Ambulance Trust to areas like East Down that no longer have an easily accessible emergency department.ldquoA major element in the solution of the social distancing problem in other emergency departments is to move immediately to reopen the Downersquos AE. That is absolutely essential.Campaigners added: ldquoThe historic underinvestment in the Ambulance Service has been widely known for years. It is a pity that it was left seriously under resourced, facing into a pandemic..prettyPhoto

title: Drumaness Superkings have convincing win away to BISC

Drumaness Superkings needed a partnership and they found that when Neil Walsh joined Amit.Amit began to find the boundary hitting some wonderful shots and had reached , including four sixes from  balls, when he was run out.Senthil joined Walsh and the pair began another useful partnership. Oldroyd then had Drawid caught at mid-on by Cunningham for one.BISC had reached  in the sixth over when Senthil and Cunningham ran out Rekhi for seven.The fourth BISC wicket fell with the score on  when Senthil bowled Arava for eight. BISCrsquos remaining wickets began to fall. Karuppan was caught at long on by Cunningham off Oldroyd, Steele then caught Bhattacharya and Cunningham caught Nagineni both from Abidrsquos bowling and Cunningham finished the match of when he bowled Kemparaje.BISC were all out for  to leave Drumaness Superkings victors by  runs. Cunningham finished with  for , Abid  for , Walsh  for  and Oldroyd  for .Drumaness Superkings are away to Dunmurry this Saturday.Match ball sponsored by Bennettyrsquos, Drumaness..prettyPhoto

title: Elliott’s winning streak at Downpatrick rolls on
story: GORDON Elliott, the regular champion trainer at Downpatrick Racecourse, was certainly glad that last Wednesdayrsquos behind closed doors meeting got the OK to go ahead.The Meath-based trainer recorded a - four timer at one of his favourite tracks.Three of his winners were ridden by his stable jockey, Davy Russell, now one of the most senior riders, following the retirement of Ruby Walsh and Barry Geraghty.The duo got off the mark in the third race of the day, the Randox Health Handicap hurdle, when Insane Bolt at - got home ahead of the - favourite Kilmurry, ridden by Nial lsquoSlippersrsquo Madden.Third was So Near So Farhh, owned by Comberrsquos James Murdoch and trained at Crossgar by Colin McBratney, who has done well since the resumption of racing. The winner then had to survive a stewardsrsquo enquiry.The duo followed up their success in the next race, the Randox Health Maiden Hurdle, when Soildels Hill put in a strong late run up the hill to win in smooth style over - shot Knot on Time and Memories Remain.With the duo not included in the following race, the third success of the day came in the second ide of theHandicap Hurdle.In this race Irsquom on Sap, owned and trained at Dromara by Neil McCluskey, set out to make the running under Eoin Walsh and still held the call at the final flight.But once Russell sent his mount Give Him Time into the lead, it was all over, the - shot beating the - favourite ldquoMiraculumand the long time leader, which stayed on for third.Despite these three wins, Elliottrsquos runner Curlew Hill, with top jockey Jamie Codd in the saddle, was an easy to back - favourite in the concluding Toals Dial-a-Bet bumper race.Always looking good, Curlew Hill won in good style over Patrick Mullins on ldquoRuaille Buaille with ldquoCrobally Boy back in third.Former champion flat jockey Joseph OrsquoBrien has been a great supporter of the local track since he set up as a trainer, and it was good to see him on the mark in the opening mares maiden hurdle when his charge, the - favourite, Etincelle Lioterie, ridden by his cousin JJ Slevin, won in good style from Rock me Robin, ridden by highly rated amateur Jordan Gainford, and Coosan Clover.There was a right old shock in the dayrsquos second race, the RandoxMaiden hurdle when the nine year-old Walkers Point emerged the winner.Always well placed under amateur Noel McParlan who sent his mount into pole position with two flights left to take the - shot, stayed on well to the post to beat the - favourite Ya Boy Yaand Felino De Bersy for the Elliott Russell combination.The winner is trained at Cabra by the jockeyrsquos father, Sean, and paid pound. on the tote. This is not the first big priced winner for the duo as they once won with a - shot across the water.This was not the only local winner of the day. In the first ision of theHandicap hurdle James Boru, the long time back marker, finished well under Conor Orr, for whom this was a welcome change of luck, to better Mary of De Sorrows and Lighthouse Rose.Noel Kelly, who has a large string at present in his care at Draperstown, trained the winner.Full marks to the starter who got all races off on the button. Sadly, for what is normally family day at the track, there were even less people in the enclosures than at the Ulster National meeting in March.Despite the recent dry spell and uncertainty about the resumption, the track was in tip top condition, so well done ground staff.Down Royal have an all-flat meeting this Friday, also behind closed doors.I was saddened recently to learn of the passing of David Armstrong of Saintfield.David was a long time supporter of local point-to-points, as an owner etc, and many will recall his late daughter, Yvonne, riding under her maiden name and her married name of Heaney. Deepest sympathy is extended to the family.David was always a nice man to meet on onersquos travels and will be sadly missed..prettyPhoto

title: Foodbank helps 1%2C100 people
story: THE Fountain Foodbank in Downpatrick helped over , people during the past  weeks of lockdown, it has been confirmed.The cross-community charity mdash based at Downpatrick Presbyterian Church ndash delivered around  food parcels as the global pandemic hit the district.Volunteers continued to deliver food parcels to those most in need with the charity extremely grateful to all those who helped in any way during what it described as ldquodficult circumstances.The scale of the pandemic forced the charity to implement a series of changes to help those in need, which included suspending its collection service.Parcels were subsequently delivered to peoplersquos homes by volunteers observing strict social distancing guidelines.Food parcels were left outside a clientrsquos door and volunteers did not enter anyonersquos homes.But this service ends next Wednesday, July .The charity has revealed that the easing of lockdown restrictions has paved the way for the foodbank toallow people to start calling at its base in Downpatrick for food parcels from next month.From Friday, August , parcels can be collected from the foodbank between am and noon with those in need of a food parcel required contact one of the foodbankrsquos referring partner organisations.Parcels need to be pre-ordered with volunteers from the referring organisations asking questions before providing a paper voucher or referring the iniduals to the foodbank via telephone or email.When the new measures governing the collection of parcels also come into force, visitors should not visit the foodbankthey are ill, while those who do call are required to wear a face mask and,possible, go alone.In addition, all callers must follow the one-way system and social distancing measures that will be in place.Hand sanitisers which have been provided must be used, with callers ready to hand over their voucher or referring information to the foodbank volunteers on duty.As the volunteers prepare for theof the collection service at their Downpatrick base, they are encouraging anyone in the community who needs help to get in touch for a referral over the coming weeks.The charity says it is particularly grateful to its donors and all those who continue to support its work, especially at what remains a dficult time for many.Food donations can continue to be made at dedicated collection points at the Asda and Supervalu supermarkets at the Ballydugan retail park and Ballymote shopping centre respectively.Everyone associated with the charity say they are grateful for all the support they continue to receive to help those in need during what are challenging times for everyone.The foodbank contact details are  , email fountainfoodbank@gmail or visit www.downpatrickpresbyterianchurch.org..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 19%2C 2000
story: CASTLEWELLAN mdash RUC chiefs have this week unveiled plans to increase the number of police patrols in the Castlewellan area in the wake of last weekendrsquos bomb attack in the town.They have also appealed to local people to be their ldquoeyes and ears in the area and confirmed the move to increase patrols is a direct response to the weekend bomb attack on  year-old civil servant Colin Laverty.A booby trap device attached underneath his Volkswagen car exploded outside his Newcastle Road home last Saturday morning with the blast sending large pieces of metal tearing through the floor of the car.Police chiefs say the former Down minor football star is lucky to be alive because although the device was crude, it had the potential to kill.The local man escaped with only minor injuries and was treated at the Downe Hospital.Army bomb disposal experts spent several hours examining the scene of the blast and combed the Volkswagen car for vital clues which could help police identy the group which planted the device. A number of items were also taken away for detailed forensic examination.NEWCASTLE ndash Newcastle received its first royal visit in over ten years when the Princess Royal visited the townrsquos leboat station to honour  years of lesaving in the area.The seaside resort was the Princessrsquo second engagement of the day. After officially opening the Strangford Yacht Club at Whiterock, she flew by helicopter to Newcastle for her afternoon appointment.After a short journey from Donard Park to the harbour, the Princess was greeted by Down Council chairman, Mr Albert Colmer, and the councilrsquos chief executive, Mr John McGrillen.The Lord Lieutenant of County Down, Major William Hall, then introduced Princess Anne to Mr Terence Johnston, the chairman of the Committee of RNLI Management in Ireland, Mr Will Wilson, chairman of Newcastle Leboat station and the stationrsquos honorary secretary, Mr Vincent Murphy.DUNDRUM ndash A leading local figurehead in Northern Ireland conservation has stepped down after  years of service with the National Trust.But Dundrum woman, Jo Whatmough, is far from ready to leave behind her lelong interest in environmental science.Having played a major role within the National Trust as its Regional Advisor since , Jo is looking forward to leaving the paperwork behind and getting back outdoors for some much-loved fieldwork.Top of her post-retirement agenda, will be the continuation of her favourite areas of biology research, including the study of a very rare butterfly found in Murlough, known as the Marsh Fritillary.Jo is also hoping to carry out some voluntary work which she says has played a large part in keeping National Trust property in the top environmental condition it is today.KILLYLEAGH mdash Planning chiefs have this week paved the way for work to start on a major new waterfront development in Killyleagh.The harbour area in the town is in line for a dramatic transformation after planners gave the green light for existing quayside buildings to be bulldozed to make way for  town houses and  apartments.Work on the new homes is expected to start within the next few months and will be carried out in tandem with a scheme to provide a new seafront walkway which will stretch from Cuan Beach to the Net Walk.The waterfront proposal has been drawn up by the townrsquos Development Association with the construction work to be carried out by McLaughlin and Harvey. The scheme is also being backed by Down Council which is providing pound, in funding over the next three years.ARDGLASS ndash Ardglass will be awash with Vikings this Saturday morning, but do not be afraid because they arenrsquot planning to come ashore to pillage.The local village will host the annual Viking Longship races and hundreds of people are expected in Ardglass for the spectacular event.Organisers say the annual races continue to grow in popularity, with the event being exported to other areas around the province.Current menrsquos, womenrsquos and mixed champions have been getting in some last minute practice before the event gets underway this Saturday at noon.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch student has been named as a finalist in the prestigious DailyBASF Young Science Writer Awards.Seventeen year-old Assumption Grammar pupil, Orla Devlin, will now go through to the final round of the competition which is designed to encourage aspiring young science writers.PORTAFERRY mdash A Portaferry man will have his services to the RNLI honoured tomorrow, when he attends a royal garden party at Buckingham Palace.Jackie Harrison, and his we, Josephine, will be among a group of leboatmen, station personnel, fundraisers and RNLI staff from the province, attending thein the presence of the Queen.Jackie was invited to London to mark his long and devoted service to the RNLI. He was a crew member between  and , becoming a shore helper in  and then deputy launching authority in .STRANGFORD mdash There was a carnival atmosphere in Strangford at the weekend as hundreds of people converged on the picturesque village to take part in the annual regatta and festival.As the summer sun shone down on the crowds, making it one of the largest festivals in the events history, organisers said they were pleased the event ran according to plan.One of the highlights had to be the colourful fancy dress parade which snaked its way through the village, led by Hollymount Pipe Band, from The Links playing fields to the Square.Another key part of the festival had to be the sports, when people of all ages came to the tiny port to compete in ious games, as well as a funfair on the Green and an open-air disco ndash all of which made the festival a great success, with locals already looking forward to next year.DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick Railway Museum was the setting recently for the launch of a cross-border project to promote the work of railways in a joint initiative with the Co Kerry town of Listowel.In what will be the largest ever North South grassroots project, a total of pound million is to be raised to enable both towns to establish new buildings for the display of carriages and associated exhibitions. Funding will also go towards increasing theof the Downpatrick railway line.KILCLIEF mdash Downpatrick Roads Service has agreed to further improve footpaths and to introduce a lay-by at the Ballycotton estate.Two sectors of the three-stage project have already been carried out, and the final work is expected to be completed in the autumn. The finishing touches will include new kerbing and an extension of the footpaths along the road way to the bus stop.GOLF mdash Tiger Woods, the worldrsquos number one golfer, arrived by helicopter on Saturday morning for a round on the world famous links of Royal County Down Golf Club.The US Open Champion has tamed some of the toughest courses in the world, but even he found Royal County Down quite a handful. He shot a one over par  and immediately declared that the course had lived up to his expectations.It was supposed to be a lsquohush hushrsquo visit, but within a couple of hours the word had spread and hundreds of fans made their way to see the hottest property in world golf.Woods came to Newcastle as part of his preparations for the British Open which starts tomorrow at St Andrewrsquos..prettyPhoto

title: Jules on top of the world at Matterhorn
story: IT was the hug at the top of the Matterhorn that told Chris Molyneaux his son was proud that he had just climbed one of the highest peaks in Europe mdash at the age of .The former Co Down man was not surprised that his youngest child, Jules, completed the arduous climb at such a young age.The naturally gted young sportsman has been loving the thrill and achievement of climbing since he was a toddler.At just under , metres high, the Matterhorn in the Swiss Alps is a challenging climb due to its sheer pyramid shape and requires rock climbing expertise and strength to scale it.The challenge is reflected in that  people have died on the mountain, including a  year-old man let Wednesday when Chris and Jules successfully completed their climb.Climbing in two pairs with an experienced mountain guide each, father and son left camp just before am and reached the summit just over four hours later.ldquoThe Matterhorn is one of the deadliest peaks in the world and on the day of our climb, there was more snow than our guide has seen in  years and there were lots of falling rocks, said Chris. ldquoBut there was no issues for Jules during the climb,. If there had have been, the guide would have stopped and taken him down.Jules was later told by the Matterhorn Museum that itrsquos believed he was the youngest person ever to have mastered the peak.Chris, now living with his family in the Scottish Highlands where he and his we Mignonne run a gin distillery, Daffyrsquos, said: ldquoJules has always loved climbing since he was able to walk. Whether it was trees or rocks, he progressed doing indoor climbing walls and roped up climbing outdoors.A former professional snowboarder, Chris grew up on Sketrick Island, near Killinchy, with his parents, Zora and Paul.He developed a love of mountains and climbing as a child in the Mournes and through his schoolrsquos mountaineering club, so it was inevitable he would pass on his passion for the outdoors to Jules and his elder brother,  year-old Louis.ldquoWersquove always climbed as a family but several years ago Jules was asked to do a school project on any subject and he chose to do one on climbing the Matterhorn, explained Chris.ldquoOne day he asked mehe could climb the Matterhorn some time and I said of course, rather thinking it was a joke.ldquoBut Jules really put in the training himself and kept pushing me to take on a hike or a climb. He was always very capable as we have always climbed as a family.Chris said that Jules continued to put the work into building up his skills and stamina for the climb mdash even the Covid- could not defeat the  year-oldrsquos determination to climb the mountain.ldquoWe had lined up an American friend of ours to guide us, but he couldnrsquot travel due to the pandemic so we thought we would go with the local mountain guides.ldquoHowever, they told Jules that he couldnrsquot do it until he was  and after he proved himself. We did a lot of high altitude extreme rock climbs. They watched Jules, saw that he was very capable and decided to give him a shot.While Chris was prepared to try and make his sonrsquos ambition to come true, even he was surprised when they safely made the summit and ed back down without incident.ldquoI donrsquot think I fully expected we would make it to the top, admitted Chris. ldquoJules gave me a hug at the very top and said he couldnrsquot believe he had done it. He thought it was incredible but it did take a while for it to sink in afterwards.While Jules may be eligible for an entry into the Guinness Book of Records, his dad said that accolade is not what Jules was about.ldquoHersquos not a glory hunter in any sense, hersquos just appreciative and proud to have done it. Jules wasnrsquot doing it for a record, he just wanted to climb the Matterhorn, for the achievement of it.And Chrisrsquos prediction of what his son might achieve in the future  ldquoIrsquom not sureJules will go for a career as a climber, hersquos more about adventure and would love to be a great adventurer whether itrsquos skateboarding, skiing, ing, sailing. Jules just loves adventure. Hersquos a very good fencer, swimmer, footballer and is a bit of an all-rounder really..prettyPhoto

title: Lighthouse campaigners continue bid to save beam
story: CAMPAIGNERS opposed to changes at the historic St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse near Killough have reaffirmed their ldquohands off warning to the Commissioner of Irish Lights.Their renewed determination to retain the lighthousersquos iconic sweeping beam and rotating mechanism mdash which turns a huge Fresnel lens mdash comes after it emerged that the Dublin-based organisation has started the tendering process to remove it.Despite widespread opposition locally, the Commissioners of Irish Lightsis seeking tenders from specialist companies to remove liquid mercury from St Johnrsquos Point and six other lighthouses across Ireland over the next six years, beginning with two on Rathlin Island.CIL is planning to replace the current rotating mechanism at the Killough lighthouse and replace the light with a modern, low-powered LED alternative, while retaining the existing lens.But campaigners are calling for the proposal to be scrapped and are concerned that tender documents have been issued, despite local politicians and residents vehemently opposing any changes at St Johnrsquos Point.CIL insists it is planning minimal changes and aims to remove mercury from the lighthousersquos current rotating lens mechanism and replace it with a German-made alternative.In addition, the organisation insists that the engineering works planned for the Killough lighthouse will deliver a ldquobetter quality, environmentally superior solution which meets modern health and safety requirements.CIL argues it is simply removing mercury out of the rotating lens system and putting in an innovative mechanical bearing solution. However, the claims have been firmly rejected by local people keen to see the controversial plan aborted.According to the tender documents, CIL wants to replace the existing beam with a more environmentally friendly LED light, maintaining that it can do this while retaining the traditional lens.And CIL says while mercury has been used to rotate large revolving Fresnel lenses since the s, with the system providing a near frictionless environment, it describes mercury as a ldquotoxic substance.While pointing to many years of reliable service, the organisation says there is increasing European and international legislation restricting the use, storage and transport of mercury.CIL maintains while it has no immediate statutory requirement to remove mercury from lighthouses, it has been its policy that where re-engineering capital projects are being carried out at lighthouses, ldquothe opportunity is taken to remove mercury.The organisation says with no other liquid medium available to replace mercury, alternative solutions are designed on a station by station basis to provide visual aid to navigation.CIL claims that trials on an alternative bearing at Tory Island lighthouse which started in  ensures the reliability of the bearing solution proposed for St Johnrsquos Point where it plans to retain the existing Fresnel lens which it recognises as important to the heritage of the station and local area.ldquoAs part of the engineering upgrade works, the mercury will be removed from existing optic installations and will be replaced by a mechanical bearing to provide an alternative rotation mechanism, states the tender documentation. ldquoOnly the liquid mercury will be removed and the remaining apparatus will be retained unchanged.ldquoIt is the intention to award the contracts for mercury removal at Rathlin East and Rathlin West lighthouses initially and appoint the successful tenderer for future removals.A spokeswoman for the Lecale Lightkeepers campaign group battling to retain the lighthouse in its current guise, suggested that local politicians will be ldquoperplexed that CIL has effectively ignored their wishes on the issue and the protection of the iconic sweeping beam.She said Newry, Mourne and Down Council unanimously decided to oppose any changes and was firmly standing alongside the local community on the issue.ldquoThe people and politicians are as one on this issue, the spokeswoman declared. ldquoSt Johnrsquos Point lighthouse is part of the arearsquos unique maritime history and heritage and must not be changed in any way.ldquoWhy is CIL issuing tender documentation when it has not told local politicians and indeed the people of Killough why it is proceeding without further discussion with them  Why is CIL ignoring the wishes of elected representatives She continued: ldquoWe have consistently asked for this beautul lighthouse to be simply left as it is. It is working perfectly andit isnrsquot broke, donrsquot fix it. We have consistently argued that the mercury issue is a red herring and nothing we have seen or heard has made us deviate from this position.ldquoSt Johnrsquos is one of the best ventilated lighthouses of its kind and we are opposed to any orce from the current Fresnel lens and its Burdel rotating mechanism.Campaigners say they hope that politicians will seek an urgent, virtual meeting with CIL to ask why their wishes have been ignored and why they were not formally told that the tendering process had begun.The campaign spokeswoman added: ldquoThe St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse boasts what is widely regarded as a rare bit of engineering excellence which we want retained and maintained. The iconic sweeping beam and rotation system must not be lost at the stroke of a pen and consigned to the pages of history. We will not let this happen..prettyPhoto

title: MoT centres open
story: DRIVERS across the district are heading back to Downpatrickrsquos MoT centre this month.The Driver and Vehicle Agencyhas begun a phasedof MoT tests, with driving tests also set to resume.MoT tests for what are being described as ldquopriority vehicle groups began on Monday and testing for other vehicles is due to recommence in August.There are also plans to reinstate some driver testing services in July, but these will only be allowed to proceedthey can be done safely and social distancing requirements can be met.Stormont infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon said ldquoofficials have been working hard to find solutions to help customers.Ms Mallon said the DVA has carried out ldquoa full review of risk assessments and developed new MoT processes that comply with all the published government public health advice and guidance.The minister continued: ldquoA number of measures have been put in place including a range of exemptions and extensions so that, as far as possible, vehicles can be kept on the road safely and most people can keep driving.ldquoCovid- has caused unprecedented dficulties for all of us and I thank our customers for their patience at this very challenging time.Ms Mallon also confirmed that new lts have been installed at  of the provincersquos test centres. MoT tests were suspended in January after faults were detected in some of the lts.The minister also said that she ldquorecognises frustrations that many people have been unable to take driving tests and the inconvenience this has caused.She confirmed that consultation is ongoing with trade unions with a view for the phasedof driving tests..prettyPhoto

title: New bypass can help regenerate Ballynahinch
story: THE new Ballynahinch bypass can help kick-start the economic regeneration of the town and provide the wider South Down tourism economy with a signicant boost.Thatrsquos the assertion of one man who for decades was at the heart of the long campaign to secure the new multi-million pound scheme.Francis Casement was a key member of Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committee for many years and alongside the late Vincent Fullam, never gave up the battle to secure a bypass first mooted in the late s.Sadly, Mr Fullam passed away earlier this year and never got to hear the news that work on the eagerly-anticipated scheme could potentially start before next March.Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon has included the near two-mile bypass in a list of strategic projects that will be progressed during the current financial year, with the Ballynahinch project effectively ready to proceed.Never before has the Ballynahinch scheme been accorded such a high priority by the Department of Infrastructure, with all attention now focusing on confirmation of a start date.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads and alleviate chronic town centre congestion and along the main approach roads to the town.The bypass mdash now at the shovel ready stage ndash is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district, with suggestions that it could take at least  months to construct.In , Mr Casement was instrumental in securing traffic counting machines in a bid to determine the number of vehicles passing through the town centre.They revealed that almost two decades ago, tens of thousands of vehicles passed through the town centre daily with particular hotspots including Main Street, Church Road, High Street, Crossgar Road, Loughside Drive and Harmony Hill Road.And while the figures were subsequently questioned by roads officials, Mr Casement and Mr Fullam, who worked alongside former town centre manager, Eric Tomasinni, were confident that their traffic count figures were spot on.Reflecting on how many years it has taken for a formal government commitment to construct the much-needed bypass, Mr Casement says he remembers plans for a new link from the Belfast Road across to Glasnevin Quarry and on to Drumaness in .ldquoThere were a number of homes along the suggested route and the road was never built. Now things have changed signicantly and the hard work of many people, including local MPs, MLAs, councillors and roads officials have paid off, he said.ldquoThere have been many  dawns over the years but we are now at the stage that work could start within a year which is good news. It is a great pity that Vincent is not here to see this happening.For a number of years, Mr Casement and Mr Fullam were the sole flag-bearers for the bypass, ensuring that the project was firmly in the public eye.While the scheme was making slow progress, the regeneration officials refused to concede defeat and organised a number of meetings, inviting business representatives from across South Down. They recognised that the construction of the bypass was as crucially important for hauliers north of Ballynahinch as it was for those as far south as Kilkeel as their lorries were often caught up in traffic hold-ups on the main approaches to and from Ballynahinch.ldquoThe support for the bypass from all quarters was overwhelming, continued Mr Casement.ldquoI have lost count of the number of locally elected and direct rule ministers who came to Ballynahinch to learn more about the bypass. Confirmation that it is now tantalisingly close proves that you must never give up, just keep chipping away and stating your case.The former regeneration official also recalled a suggestion to construct the bypass and recoup the money spent on building it by charging drivers to use it.He said while there were some opposed to the idea, a number of leading hauliers were in favour as it would save them not only time, but fuel costs as lorries would not be sitting in traffic burning diesel.ldquoIt has been a long haul to get to this point and so many people have worked hard on this project. Successive isional roads managers were in favour of the bypass but there was never the money to work on its finer detail and move it to the shovel-ready stage, explained Mr Casement. ldquoThat position subsequently changed and the scheme has now reached a pivotal point.While the primary focus of the bypass is on easing traffic congestion, Mr Casement said the scheme brings with it a number of benefits.ldquoReducing tailbacks will help the environment and perhaps one of the most important aspects of the bypass is that will deter drivers from using a number of heavily populated housing areas as unofficial bypasses, including the Loughside, Carlisle Park and Langley Road areas, he continued.ldquoThe bypass can hopefully kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre, encouraging new retailers and more shoppers. I believe that the current congestion can deter people who decide to shop where.Mr Casement said the proposed bypass can also benefit the wider South Down area as visitors from Belfast will be able to avoid Ballynahinch town centre.ldquoBallynahinch is regarded as the gateway to the Mournes and that position will be firmly cemented when the new link road opens. The scheme has never been this close in my letime and I hope that it wonrsquot be long before contractors are on the ground.ldquoBallynahinch residents and the townrsquos business community deserve this scheme. It is decades overdue and when it was confirmed recently that the project is well placed on the list of priority government schemes I was delighted.ldquoBut I was conscious that my good friend Vincent was not here to enjoy a moment that he had dedicated a large part of his le to achieving.With all eyes now on the Department for Infrastructure to confirm a bypass start date, Mr Casement hopes that it will be soon.ldquoIt has taken signicantly longer to reach this point than any of us ever imagined, but we have made it, added Mr Casement. ldquoThe icing on the cake will be confirmation of a start date and people are eagerly awaiting this announcement..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle Lions Club members celebrate 100 years’ service
story: THREE members of Newcastle Lions Club have received longstanding service awards after clocking more than  years of service between them.Club president Marian McGreevy hosted a socially distanced event last Thursday to celebrate the hard-working lions.Some  years ago Michael Niblett and Peter May, along with a host of others in Newcastle, began the Newcastle Lions Club. They were joined five years later by Terry OrsquoReilly.The three Lions have since been involved in numerous projects to help people in their own community and bigger worldwide groups.In addition their charitable fundraising which help local projects, they organised a -tonne container filled with toiletries, blankets and clothing to help people caught up in the war in Kosovo in .Ten years later the Lions began a two-year programme in primary and post primary schools to help raise theprofile of the achievement of local inventor Harry Ferguson who made a flight along the beach in Newcastle on August , .Since , the three Lions have been involved in work with the family of the late Geoff Cartwright in raising funds to help install  defibrillators. The popular Newcastle pensioner died in  after being knocked down close to his home.The Lions also trained  people in the use of the defibrillators with the help of the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service.Marian said: ldquoOver the years Terry, Michael and Peter have helped their fellow Lions to lsquothink outside the boxrsquo and made the profile of the club something to be proud of.ldquoWith their help, Newcastle Lions has survived a dficult year and membership has increased during this pandemic, and looks forward to a better future continuing to help those in need..prettyPhoto

title: Peter runs marathon in aid of poor in Philippines
story: A LOCAL student has run a marathon to raise money for a Northern Irish charity which supports poor families in the Philippines.Like many other charities, Ten Foundations has struggled to raise funds during the Coronavirus crisis.Twenty year-old Peter Gilmore, from Whiterock, near Killinchy, had planned to run the Belfast Marathon in May in aid of the charity.When it was postponed and then cancelled, Peter decided he had to do something anyway, so he recently ran his own solo marathon. His effort has so far raised over pound,.Setting out from the Ten Foundations shop on the Lisburn Road in Belfast, Peter ran a route to his home which turned out to be slightly over the official marathon distance.Conditions were challenging, with fierce wind and rain at times but Peter enjoyed great support along the way from family and friends.ldquoTen Foundations means the world to me, he said. ldquoSeeing the dference this charity makes to impoverished families in the Philippines is inspiring and thatrsquos what drove me to do this run.Ten Foundations trains and enables women in the Philippines to makes schoolbags and backpacks which are sold by volunteers in Northern Ireland.Ian Campbell, founder of Ten Foundations, said: ldquoThe last few months have been very dficult. Normally at this time of year we would be visiting lots of schools, telling them about what we do and selling our bags.ldquoWe are delighted to have reopened our Lisburn Road shop recently and we are also selling more online than before.ldquoBut now, more than ever, we really appreciate the generosity of donations and fundraising activities like this.Peter added ldquoIf you want to support Ten Foundations and the work that they do, nexttime you are buying a bag, why not buy one that can change a le For more information about Ten Foundations go to www.tenfoundations.org..prettyPhoto

title: Runners flying at Down Royal
story: WITH the postponement and then cancellation of the Belfast Marathon, there was an offer to complete the marathon distance of . miles at a place and time of your choosing.Some opted to complete the miles in one fell swoop and others took the option to spread it out over a longer period.Well done to Maureen Kelly, Eamon Kelly, Clare Carson, Kevin Kelly, Hallie Jennings, Catherine Gilchrist and Joe Quinn for having the motivation to complete the challenge.It was good to have a target at the height of lockdown that could be achieved without breaking any of the guidelines.Then with the easing of certain restrictions there came an event to allow side by side competition albeit with social distancing applied.Glenn Grant of Championchip Ireland organised a series of races over ying distances using Down Royal Racecourse as a venue.The event, the first races in the UK since the coronavirus lockdown, was sponsored by Forestside Shopping Centre. The athletes were ided into waves of  according to their expected finish times and some impressive times were recorded.East Down was well represented by those who turned out to see how their solo training had worked out for them.In the K race, Neil Curran and Mackenzie Murray were in close contention throughout with Mackenzie pulling out a fast finish to ease a few seconds ahead of Neil and also break free from junior Joel Chambers of Willowfield.In the end Neil, Joel and Marc Devlinrecorded the same time of .. Mackenziersquos finish time of . represents a huge step up in pace and is a just reward for his efforts to keep in shape over the shutdown period. Mackenzie came sixth overall with Neil in joint seventh place.Adam Morgan also ran well, clocking . for the K. Kelly Smith was very pleased with . as a new personal best time at that distance.Not to be outdone, Suzy Smith also marked a new PB with . which should really boost her confidence. It seems no time since she was working to break the -minute barrier so real progress has been made by both these runners.In the K there was an ldquoelite race which was the focus for many top athletes as they tested their legs on the flat course and against each other.The race was won by Olympic marathon hopeful and former Jimmyrsquos Ten winner Stephen Scullion in ., to really set a very high standard. His time was over half a minute faster than he ran in the European Championships in Berlin two years ago.Aaron McGrady was th in . mdash not a PB by any means but a solid performance in this time of limbo.Jimmy Sloan has been raring to go since Jimmyrsquos  was called off and he showed himself race fit with a . finish for th place, which was some two minutes  seconds faster than his previous personal best. He was over the moon with this result.The womenrsquos race was won by Ann-Marie McGlynn in a new NI record time of ., with Jessica Craig nd in . and Gemma McDonald third in ..East Downrsquos Hannah Somani, only just missed on a podium place but broke  minutes in . with relative comfort. This was a particularly laudable effort and particularly pleasing for her given that she has only just ed from an injury which prevented her from training for more than two months.ConnemaraCheryl Denvir and Lisa Milligan also deserve a shout out for their weekend exploits. They were in Connemara for the Gaelforce Adventure Race which according to the race brief is a ldquostunning route involving cycling and running through the Inagh Valley, Glen Valley, Maamturk   Ben Mountain ranges, Western Way Trail and kayaking on the crystal clear waters of the Killary Fjord in the shadow of Connaughtrsquos highest mountain Mweelrea. This is Connemara from the inside out. This route with its ied terrain and dramatic views will keep you interested and get you over the line before you know it.I am not sure that they would agree with it being over before they realised mdash the run alone was a mud bath and the cycle was testing to say the least. However both athletes did themselves proud finishing well up the rankings on a tough day out.Over  entered the event and there were a fair number of DNFs. Cheryl finished in th position with a total time of two hours and  minutes. Lisa was home within the three-hour barrier and in the top half of the field, coming th.Even better, she was a clear winner in the F category with her nearest competition more than half an hour behind her Well done you two.The half marathon race was won by the redoubtable Tommy Hughes, aka the lsquoMarrakesh Expressrsquo, in a time of ., which would be a mark most would give their eye teeth to achieve.Given that Tommy is now in the over  age category, it is nothing short of incredible. Well done to him..prettyPhoto

title: Spa Wells group delivers 60 good parcels to residents
story: MEMBERS and volunteers of Spa Wells Cultural Association distributed  food parcels in the area recently.The parcels were delivered to elderly residents and those shielding due to coronavirus.While the lockdown restrictions continue to ease, the association says it is aware that things are still far from normal.A spokesman said distributing food parcels was one small way to help neighbours, relieve social isolation and improve the quality of le of the local community.Residents were grateful to receive non-perishable items and vacuum-packed fresh meat from Poole Butchers. The parcels also contained hand sanitiser bottles from Hinch Distillery.The spokesman added: ldquoSpa Wells Cultural Association would like to thank the Community Foundation for Northern Ireland, County Down Rural Community Network and Hinch Distillery for making this project possible..prettyPhoto

title: Tests on Newcastle Centre ground for redevelopment
story: GROUND condition tests at the site of the Newcastle Centre ahead of its major redevelopment are due to recommence shortly.Itrsquos understood the work will focus on land to the side and rear of the complex, including the outdoor Tropicana swimming pool which is not expected to reopen this summer. This particular facility could also be bulldozed as part of an ambitious redevelopment proposal.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is preparing to press head with investigative work at the prime Central Promenade location mdash including bore hole tests mdash to gather as much information as possible before it presses ahead with a multi-million pound investment.Council officials say that they recognise the need for modern leisure and community facilities at the site of the Newcastle Centre with several options on the table.They include a complete rebuild which include an extension to the existing centre, a complete refurbishment of the complex or partial rebuild and partial refurbishment.Retaining the Tropicana pool would restrict redevelopment proposals and the outdoor facility is most likely to be demolished, with enhanced car parking also set to be a key plank of any new proposal, in tandem with signicant disabled access improvements.A detailed feasibility study looked at a number of potential locations for a new leisure and community facility in the resort, with the Newcastle Centre site emerging as the firm favourite to house the new facility.Council officials say they are looking at a number of possibilities and that ldquoall options for the redevelopment of the town centre site are on the table.The existing Newcastle Centre forms part of the historic Annesley Buildings which enjoys protected status, but itrsquos believed that the cost of redeveloping the property and replacing the old extension at the rear would be signicant.It is also believed that an added problem facing the council is that the size of the existing centrersquos rooms are too small and unsuitable for modern needs. One possibility is that the facade of the current building would be retained, with a new-build at the rear.Council officials say that any plan to redevelop the Central Promenade site will not impact on any part of the promenade at the rear of the building.They insist that they are committed to the Newcastle project and recognise that it has a key role to play, meeting the needs of local people and visitors alike, particularly during inclement weather.It has also been confirmed that local people are to be asked for their views on redeveloping the site as part of a pre-planning application process, to come up with a favourable design.Senior council officials say that they recognise that as one of Northern Irelandrsquos premier tourist resorts, Newcastle does not have a modern indoor facility which has been its Achilles heel for some considerable time.Two sites were previously identied for a new leisure centre in the resort, with sports pitches at Donard Park the preferred option.However, councillors subsequently switched attention to the former St. Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School campus at Shanslieve Drive. Despite a number of attempts to secure the site and hopes that a deal could be agreed with local church officials, it was bought by supermarket giant Lidl.Politicians are keen for Newry, Mourne and Down Council to take the lead and ensure that a high class leisure community facility, which has been talked about in the resort for decades, is finally delivered.They insist that the provision of modern accommodation in the heart of Newcastle is long overdue and that the lsquoonce in a generationrsquo opportunity to deliver a modern, indoor facility must not be squandered.Some politicians say it is also critical to maximise every available square inch of space at the site to deliver a high quality centre..prettyPhoto
